The passage highlights recent tennis results involving Novak Djokovic. Djokovic and his Serbian team lost 6-4, 6-4 to Brazilians Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in Rio. This followed Djokovic's singles defeat by Juan Martin del Potro. Earlier, Djokovic, the world number one, suffered a surprising third-round loss at Wimbledon in July to Sam Querrey. However, he rebounded to win his 30th Masters title in Toronto before the Olympics. The passage also mentions subscribing to the BBC Sport newsletter for updates.

The passage describes an upcoming chainsaw carving competition in Carrbridge, Cairngorms, featuring over 20 competitors from Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada, and the US. Participants are restricted to using only chainsaws to carve logs into shapes of animals and people. Last year's winner, Pete Bowsher from Moffat, will return to defend his title and retain the Claymore Trophy.

Webb, a 27-year-old Welsh rugby player, has been recovering from a serious foot injury sustained in September during a World Cup warm-up match against Italy. He is nearing a return to play, aiming to regain fitness before the Six Nations tournament in February. Webb is currently in a pre-season training phase and is optimistic about his progress. He hopes to return by early February, potentially a couple of weeks earlier than initially planned. Wales' Six Nations campaign begins on 7 February against Ireland in Dublin. Webb, who has earned 16 caps for Wales, recently renewed his dual contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, choosing to stay with his home region despite other offers. He expressed his commitment to both Ospreys and the national team, emphasizing his desire to play for Wales.

On Tuesday morning, US border agents near Sumas, Washington, encountered two men carrying backpacks containing 58lb (26kg) of ecstasy, attempting to smuggle the drugs from Canada to San Francisco. One man, Jeffrey Laviolette, was arrested immediately, while the other, Nathan Hall, fired at agents and fled. Hall was later arrested in British Columbia. Investigators also arrested Kali Henifin and Ryan Lambert, who allegedly planned to transport the drugs. The suspects face charges of conspiracy, drug possession, and distribution. The area is known as a smuggling route for drugs and firearms.

The NSPCC's Childline service reported a significant increase in the number of children counselled for online abuse, with over 4,500 cases in the past year compared to about 2,400 in 2011-12. The actual number of children suffering from online abuse is believed to be much higher. Children as young as seven have reported being tormented and scared to attend school due to online bullying. Dame Esther Rantzen, Childline's president, emphasized the severe impact of cyber-bullying, which can follow children home and become inescapable. She urged adults, parents, and teachers to intervene, as bullying tends to worsen without action. The report was released at the start of Anti-Bullying Week, coordinated by the Anti-Bullying Alliance, which is working with various stakeholders to address the issue. A young person shared their experience of being told to kill themselves by online peers, highlighting the emotional toll and the lack of understanding from parents. Advice from young people on dealing with bullying includes seeking help and not facing it alone.

The passage discusses the tensions between Israel and the United States following the UN Security Council's resolution condemning Israeli settlement construction in the West Bank and East Jerusalem. The US abstained from vetoing the resolution, which Israel views as illegal under international law, leading to anger from Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. Netanyahu accused the US of aiding the resolution's passage, a claim denied by the US State Department. In response, Israel took diplomatic actions against countries that supported the resolution, including recalling ambassadors and cutting aid. A planned vote on new settlement homes was postponed to avoid further straining US-Israel relations ahead of US Secretary of State John Kerry's speech on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Kerry is expected to outline a vision for peace and address criticisms of the Obama administration by Israel. Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas welcomed the resolution, seeing it as a step toward the upcoming Middle East peace conference in France.

The passage discusses events and statements surrounding the Queen's 90th birthday celebrations. Prince William, in a BBC interview, praised the Queen as a guiding example of a good monarch, emphasizing her duty, service, and commitment. He also addressed criticisms about his own engagement with royal duties, stating he takes his responsibilities seriously but aims to balance duty with a normal life. The Queen participated in various events, including visiting Windsor's Royal Mail delivery office and unveiling a new bandstand, accompanied by the Duke of Edinburgh. Political leaders, including Prime Minister David Cameron, expressed their admiration for the Queen's service. Additionally, special stamps featuring four generations of the Royal Family were released to mark the occasion. The Queen's birthday celebrations included lighting beacons and a planned lunch with US President Barack Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama. Critics, however, argued that the extensive media coverage of the Queen's birthday was disproportionate.

In a match between Cheltenham Town (League Two) and West Ham United (Premier League), West Ham secured a 2-0 victory with first-half goals from Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew. Despite a respectful performance from Cheltenham, they failed to sufficiently test West Ham's goalkeeper Adrian. West Ham, having made seven changes after recent Premier League losses, dominated but missed several chances to extend their lead. Cheltenham's best opportunity came from Harry Pell's volley, but substitute Dan Holman couldn't convert. The match ended Cheltenham Town 0, West Ham United 2, eliminating League Two's representation from the EFL Cup.

Aidan McNicholl, a 36-year-old hospital radiographer, died in a collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion when Andreas Werner, a 46-year-old father-of-four from Leipzig, failed to see McNicholl's motorcycle while turning right in his VW Transporter. Werner pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving at Llandudno Magistrates' Court, resulting in a £1,000 fine and a two-year UK driving ban. The victim's family expressed that they saw no benefit in Werner being jailed, acknowledging the incident as a momentary lapse. Werner's defense highlighted his remorse and inability to explain the crash.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old from Southall, London, is one of the most dangerous British jihadists to return from Syria, where he was a prominent member of the Rayat al Tawheed group, affiliated with Islamic State. Known online as Abu Daigham al-Britani, Khawaja posted propaganda videos and images, including gruesome content, to recruit and inspire British Muslims. He attempted to return to the UK in June 2014, faking his own death with an online obituary and seeking help from his cousin, Tahir Bhatti, who has admitted to assisting him. Upon arrival in Dover, Khawaja was arrested and now faces life imprisonment for terrorism-related offenses. He has admitted to four charges, while Bhatti has pleaded guilty to assisting an offender. Khawaja was held in a high-security unit at Belmarsh prison due to his perceived danger. His exact activities in Syria and reasons for returning remain unclear.

Jackson, 22, scored four goals in 36 appearances for Wrexham last season, helping them finish eighth in the table. He has signed with Barnsley as their third signing for the upcoming season, turning down a contract offer from Wrexham. Barnsley's caretaker manager, Paul Heckingbottom, praised Jackson's pace and attacking style, stating he will fit well into the team's playing style. This signing comes ahead of Barnsley's League One play-off final at Wembley on Sunday.

A container believed to have fallen from a ship during stormy weather has resulted in sealed bottles of detergent washing up on beaches in Cornwall, including Poldhu Cove, Gunwalloe, Polurrian, Church Cove, and Marazion. The National Trust and volunteers are clearing the bottles, which pose a risk to wildlife, particularly marine life, due to potential leaks. The Maritime and Coastguard Agency noted that while the MV Blue Ocean lost a container of 'Vanish' detergent near Land's End in May, there is no direct evidence linking the washed-up bottles to this incident. Authorities, including Cornwall Council, are monitoring the situation and advising the public to avoid the bottles. The company Vanish has not yet commented.

A crash occurred on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness around 14:00, resulting in minor injuries to several people. The road was closed, with diversions set up via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road. Police Scotland confirmed that investigations into the incident are ongoing.

Dorian Dervite, a 28-year-old French centre-back, made 14 appearances for Bolton Wanderers last season, contributing to their second-place finish in League One and subsequent promotion to the Championship. Having joined Bolton from Charlton in 2014, Dervite has made 83 appearances in all competitions. Manager Phil Parkinson praised his significant contribution towards the end of the season, despite being somewhat overlooked earlier. Dervite has now signed a new contract with Bolton, joining teammates David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan in securing their futures with the club following promotion.

The passage describes tensions between the Liberal Democrats (Lib Dems) and Labour over their cooperation on Brexit-related issues and other legislative matters. While the two parties previously collaborated to challenge the government on EU citizens' rights and parliamentary approval for a Brexit deal, their alliance fractured when MPs rejected these amendments. The Lib Dems accused Labour of conceding to the government and aligning with Conservatives on a hard Brexit, while Labour criticized the Lib Dems for creating "false hope" and engaging in political grandstanding. Despite their history of forming alliances on issues like higher education and housing, a Labour source predicted ongoing tensions, suggesting future cooperation would remain strictly professional rather than friendly. The Lib Dems, however, expressed willingness to continue working with peers across the House on shared priorities.

The passage highlights the declining priority of defence in the UK's political agenda, with defence issues ranking low among voter concerns, overshadowed by the economy, the NHS, and immigration. Public fatigue from past military interventions and political reticence have contributed to this trend. Despite global instability and increasing threats, the UK has significantly reduced its armed forces, with the regular Army shrinking and the Royal Navy and RAF facing cuts. Defence spending has fallen, with the UK now sixth globally, and is projected to drop below NATO's 2% GDP target. Political parties, except for UKIP and the Democratic Unionist Party, have not committed to maintaining this target. The Ministry of Defence faces potential further budget cuts, with no party pledging to protect defence spending. The renewal of Trident, the UK's nuclear deterrent, is a contentious issue, with differing views among parties. The UK's military capabilities are strained, with concerns over manning levels and equipment. The passage underscores the challenges in maintaining the UK's global military influence amidst fiscal constraints and shifting political priorities.

The passage discusses the controversy surrounding Barcelona's signing of Neymar from Santos. Barcelona paid £48.6 million for Neymar, with his parents receiving £34 million of the fee. Including various fees and wages, the total cost of the transfer is estimated at £106.8 million. Former Barcelona president Sandro Rosell resigned amid accusations of misappropriating funds related to the transfer, though he denies wrongdoing. A Spanish judge ruled there is sufficient evidence to continue investigating the transfer. Barcelona denies any tax-related crimes and has made an additional tax payment of 13,550,830.56 euros to address potential discrepancies, while maintaining that their original payment was correct. The case's status remains unclear. Neymar has scored seven goals in 18 league appearances and three in seven Champions League matches this season.

Michael Luciw, a 27-year-old from Nottingham, died in a motorway crash when a van he was a passenger in was hit by a Mazda Premacy driven the wrong way by Albert Kenneth Newman, who also died. Mr. Luciw's family has called for regular driving tests for older drivers, arguing that age can slow reaction times. They described Mr. Luciw as a kind-hearted father who was looking forward to his baby daughter's milestones. The crash occurred near Kegworth, Leicestershire, and the van's driver, Andy Harrington, sustained serious injuries and also supports stricter driving assessments for retirees. Currently, UK drivers over 70 must renew their licenses every three years via a self-assessment form, without a medical or driving test. The DVLA stated there is no evidence that older drivers are more likely to cause serious accidents and emphasized that licenses are revoked if medical standards are not met. Age UK highlighted the importance of driving for older people's independence and advocated for supporting safe driving as long as possible.

The passage discusses concerns over the safety of transvaginal mesh implants used to treat incontinence and pelvic organ prolapse, following reports of debilitating side effects. An independent review, led by Professor Alison Britton, will examine the process and conclusions of a controversial final report. The report recommended against routine use of these procedures, advocating for informed patient choices and mandatory reporting of adverse events. Despite calls for a ban, the Scottish government stated it lacks the authority to do so, as regulation falls under the UK's Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency. The review process faced significant criticism, with two patients and a consultant resigning in protest, citing dissatisfaction with the report's conclusions and alleged omissions. Over 20,000 women in Scotland have received these implants in the past two decades, with over 400 currently pursuing legal action against health boards and manufacturers due to complications.

Laura Muir, aged 23, broke Liz McColgan's 25-year-old 5,000m indoor record by 14 seconds, finishing in 14 minutes and 49.12 seconds at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow. McColgan expressed excitement about her record being broken by Muir but initially raised concerns about the race's validity, questioning if it met UK Athletics' criteria for record ratification, particularly regarding the race's competitiveness and drug testing. However, British Athletics confirmed that Muir's time is expected to be officially ratified, noting that drug testing is not required for record ratification if no doping control is present at the event. McColgan praised Muir's performance, suggesting she has the potential to run even faster and compete at the world's top level. She also highlighted the significance of her record being broken by another Scot and emphasized Muir's world-class ability, advising her to refine her race tactics to win medals. Muir has previously broken her own British 1,500m record and reached the Olympic final in that event at Rio 2016.

Jung won the event riding Sam, a replacement for Fischertakinou, who fell ill in July. France's Astier Nicolas secured silver, and American Phillip Dutton took bronze, while Britain's William Fox-Pitt finished 12th. Fox-Pitt, competing just 10 months after a serious fall that left him in an induced coma, delivered a flawless show-jumping performance but had already lost his medal chance due to time penalties in the cross-country phase. Ireland's Jonty Evans finished ninth. The passage also promotes equestrian activities and a BBC Sport newsletter.

The passage describes a tennis match between Andy Murray and Fabio Fognini at Wimbledon. Murray won the match 6-2, 4-6, 6-1, 7-5 in two hours and 39 minutes, securing his place in the last 16 for the 11th time. Fognini had five set points to force a fifth set, but Murray won five consecutive games to clinch the victory. Murray will face Benoit Paire in the fourth round. The match was tense, with Murray acknowledging it wasn't his best tennis but expressing relief at winning in four sets. Fognini showed moments of brilliance but struggled with errors and an ankle injury. Murray praised his fighting spirit and looked forward to improving his game for the next round. Fellow Briton Johanna Konta also advanced to the second week of the tournament.

On 6 October 2014, paramedics responded to a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST. Police found people still at the bar, with evidence of alcohol being served until 04:49 BST. The bar was ordered to close for three months. Colleen O'Neill, the license holder, was charged with two counts of allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours, while James Thomas faced one count of the same charge. The defence acknowledged lax adherence to licensing laws and improper management of the premises. The judge criticized O'Neill's "appalling record" and expressed frustration over the inability to impose a custodial sentence. O'Neill was fined £3,000, and Thomas was fined £1,000.

Mike Nesbitt, leader of the Ulster Unionists, emphasized the importance of partnership over domination during the launch of his party's manifesto, titled 'Real Partnership'. The manifesto focuses on key issues such as reducing healthcare waiting lists, increasing police numbers, improving infrastructure, supporting the LGBT community, and ensuring no group is disadvantaged by Brexit. Nesbitt framed the upcoming election as a referendum on the handling of the Renewable Heat Incentive scandal, criticizing the Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) and Sinn Féin for their governance. Despite controversy over his comments advocating for vote transfers to the nationalist Social Democratic and Labour Party (SDLP), Nesbitt stood by his remarks, expressing confidence in his position and support from unionist areas. He highlighted the need for accountability and change in Stormont, targeting issues like incompetence, arrogance, and corruption.

Justice Minister Claire Sugden announced that a motion will be presented to the Northern Ireland Assembly to align with England and Wales in granting automatic pardons to men convicted of now-abolished sexual offences, both posthumously and for living individuals. Known as 'Turing's Law', this initiative allows living men to apply for pardons and aims to ensure equal treatment for gay and bisexual men in Northern Ireland. The minister emphasized the importance of addressing past injustices and expediting the process through a legislative consent motion, which is expected to be considered by the assembly soon.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old from Kinross, set a new Scottish record in the 1500m with a time of 4:19.12, finishing second behind Kenyan Faith Kipyegon. This performance surpassed Yvonne Murray's 1994 record of 4:22.60 and placed Muir second on the British all-time list behind Zola Budd's 4:17.57. Muir, who also holds the Scottish 1500m and mile records, expressed her delight at the achievement, especially as it was her first race of the season over this distance. She aims to secure a place for the Olympics in Rio at the upcoming British trials in Birmingham. Muir, who balances her training with veterinary studies, recently completed her fourth year of vet school and started her season with an 800m victory in France. She will next compete in a 1500m race in Stockholm.

The passage mentions a collection of pictures from 26 beaches in Scotland that have been ranked as having the "most excellent" water quality. The core information is that these beaches are recognized for their high water quality, and the passage highlights this through the presentation of associated pictures.

The passage discusses the 2006 poisoning of Alexander Litvinenko in London, where he ingested polonium-210 during a meeting with suspects Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi, leading to his death nearly three weeks later. Richard Horwell QC, representing the Metropolitan Police, stated that the Russian state was likely the sponsor of the plot, citing Litvinenko's defection to the UK and his criticisms of Russian President Vladimir Putin as possible motives. However, Horwell clarified that there was no evidence implicating Putin directly. The suspects, who deny wrongdoing, left traces of polonium and have not provided credible explanations for the scientific evidence against them. Extradition attempts have failed, and the likelihood of a trial is low. The inquiry also noted the unknown risks of polonium exposure to the public and adjourned until Friday.

Steve Smith, aged 26, has been appointed as the captain of Australia's one-day and Twenty20 cricket teams, replacing the injured Aaron Finch. David Warner, 28, has been named as Smith's vice-captain. Smith, who has previously captained the team in three Tests against India, is highly regarded by selectors for his talent and leadership qualities. His appointment follows Michael Clarke's retirement after Australia's Ashes defeat. Smith has played 32 Tests, scoring 2,952 runs with an average of 54.66. Warner, despite past disciplinary issues, is seen as having matured and is expected to handle the added responsibility well. Smith and Warner will lead the team in upcoming limited-overs matches after the final Ashes Test.

Tim Farron, leader of the Liberal Democrats, expressed strong support for LGBT+ rights and equal marriage during interviews on the BBC's Andrew Marr Show and Channel 4 News. He emphasized that defending equal marriage and extending marital rights for transgender people would be top priorities during his leadership. However, he avoided directly answering whether he believed homosexual sex was a sin, instead stating that "we are all sinners." Farron also defended his 2007 vote against the Equality Bill, citing concerns about "protection of individual liberties," though he did not specify what those concerns were. He clarified that he supports equal legal access for all people regardless of sexuality and highlighted the need to address the spousal veto, which restricts transgender people's access to marriage.

Accord Healthcare is set to take over the former Sanofi drug manufacturing site in Fawdon, which closed in 2015, resulting in 450 job losses. The new investment aims to create pharmaceutical production jobs, potentially employing many former Sanofi staff. Accord Healthcare, a global pharmaceutical company producing over 130 products for around 60 countries, expects the move to positively impact the local economy. Newcastle City Council leader Nick Forbes praised the announcement as a boost to the region's reputation in the science and healthcare sectors.

The passage reports the departure of three senior staff members from the local council: Richard Ellis, who is leaving at the end of his contract; Ciaran Monaghan and Ewan Sutherland, who are departing under voluntary redundancy and early retirement schemes. Richard Ellis served as the interim director of corporate governance and deputy chief executive, while Monaghan was head of the chief executive's office, and Sutherland led human resources and customer services. Stephen Flynn, the opposition SNP group leader, criticized the council for its inability to retain senior staff and predicted more departures. Council chief executive Angela Scott expressed gratitude for their dedication and professionalism.

The English rider, Martin, experienced a crash at this year's TT and faced ongoing mechanical issues with his Fireblade bike. Initially, he announced his retirement from road racing but later clarified on Facebook that he hasn't given up on racing entirely, though he has no plans to race Hondas this year. Martin did not participate in the North West 200 after his teammate John McGuinness crashed during practice and will also skip the upcoming Ulster Grand Prix. He described the TT as a "bloody disaster," feeling more like a test rider than a competitor. After further testing at Cadwell, he concluded the bike wouldn't be competitive for the Ulster Grand Prix, leading the team to withdraw him from the event without informing him. Martin expressed no unfinished business in road racing and now aims to focus on racing classics and unique events.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) secured a significant victory in Nigeria's state elections, winning 19 out of 28 governor posts, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since the end of military rule in 1999. The PDP, which lost the presidential election last month for the first time, managed to retain only eight governorships, mostly in the south-east, and lost key northern states. The APC's gains have relegated the PDP to a regional party, with the APC controlling most northern states and Lagos, Nigeria's commercial hub. However, the APC failed to win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, raising concerns for President-elect Muhammadu Buhari about potential disruptions to oil revenue. The elections were marred by violence in some areas, but overall were more peaceful than in previous years, indicating a maturing democracy. The PDP faces a period of introspection and rebuilding after 16 years in power, amid allegations of corruption and failure to address the Islamist insurgency in the north-east.

The passage discusses allegations by the US-based environmental group Mighty against Olam, an agricultural commodities trader, and its main stakeholder, Temasek, a Singapore state-owned investment company. Mighty accuses Olam of contributing to environmental degradation through unsustainable palm oil trading practices, which may exacerbate the haze affecting Singapore, Malaysia, and Indonesia. Olam denies these claims, stating it has a strict "no burn-no peat-no deforestation" policy and sources 99% of its palm oil from third-party suppliers, accounting for less than 1% of the global market. Olam has agreed to disclose its suppliers and claims to enforce sustainable practices, though verification is ongoing. Temasek also rejects the allegations, emphasizing its support for no-burn policies and proper governance. The passage highlights broader issues in the palm oil industry, including deforestation, illegal labor practices, and the challenges of regulating third-party suppliers. Additionally, Mighty raises concerns about Olam's practices in Gabon, where it is accused of clearing rainforests for palm oil plantations. Olam defends its operations in Gabon as responsible and transparent, aligning with the country's agricultural development goals.

The passage describes a restaurant that started serving puppy platters following a new law permitting dogs to dine at restaurants, provided they are seated outdoors. The text humorously notes the situation as a "dog's dinner" and references a related clip.

Fernando Forestieri is doubtful for the next game due to a knee injury, having only appeared as a substitute in the last two matches. Derby County's David Nugent may return after recovering from a groin injury that kept him out of the recent draw with Huddersfield. Jacob Butterfield, who scored a late equalizer after coming off the bench in that game, is hoping to be recalled to the starting lineup.

Pakistan's telecoms regulator lifted a ban on YouTube, which had been in place since 2012 after the controversial film *Innocence of Muslims* sparked protests and was deemed blasphemous. The ban was lifted because Google launched a Pakistan-specific version of YouTube, allowing authorities to request the blocking of offending content directly through an online process. However, YouTube clarified that government requests for content removal would not be automatically granted and would undergo a thorough review. While many young Pakistanis welcomed the ban's lifting, activists called for greater transparency regarding the terms of the agreement between Google and the government. The Pakistan Telecommunication Authority confirmed that all internet service providers were instructed to restore access to YouTube.

Domenico Scala, head of FIFA's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, faces criticism from Musa Bility, president of the Liberian Football Association, for not stepping down due to a perceived conflict of interest, as Scala shares Swiss-Italian nationality with presidential candidate Gianni Infantino. Bility argues that Article 7.4 of FIFA's Electoral Regulations mandates that committee members with conflicts of interest must be replaced, citing Scala's withdrawal in the 2015 elections when he shared nationality with then-candidate Sepp Blatter. Scala's spokesman, Andreas Bantel, counters that no conflict exists, as there is no incumbent president in this election, and Scala's previous withdrawal was voluntary. Bility threatens to take the matter to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not step down by Thursday. The election to replace Blatter, involving five candidates, will occur on 26 February in Zurich. Bility, who was barred from running, supports Prince Ali and urges African nations to do the same.

Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, were killed in an explosion at Harford Attachments in Spar Road while working in a paint-spraying area on Monday morning. Their bodies were removed on Tuesday. Forensic evidence suggests a flashover explosion caused by a buildup of toxic fumes and an ignition source, resulting in a fireball. The Health and Safety Executive is investigating, and significant progress has been made in forensic inquiries and witness statements. The company manufactures digger buckets.

Tunisia faced potential expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations after lodging complaints against the Confederation of African Football (Caf) following a controversial quarter-final loss to Equatorial Guinea in 2015. Tunisia accused the referee of poor decisions but denied allegations of corruption. After a meeting with Caf president Issa Hayatou, Tunisia apologized, resolving the dispute and securing their participation in the 2017 tournament. Meanwhile, Morocco, initially banned and fined for refusing to host the 2015 Nations Cup due to Ebola concerns, had their ban overturned by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) and their fine reduced, allowing them to enter the 2017 qualifiers. Both nations are now set to compete in the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations, with Tunisia aiming for a record 13th consecutive appearance.

The passage describes a post-match incident during a football game at Etihad Stadium, where Chelsea defeated Manchester City 3-1. During the 95th minute, a mass altercation occurred, leading to the dismissal of City's Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho. Aguero received a four-match ban for violent conduct after a late challenge on Chelsea's David Luiz, while Fernandinho was given a three-match ban for his involvement in the subsequent scuffle with Chelsea's Cesc Fabregas, who faced no further action. City manager Pep Guardiola apologized for his team's role in the incident. Both clubs have until 18:00 GMT on 8 December to respond to the charge.

The passage discusses a pilot scheme in Cwm Cynon and Neath, Wales, aimed at improving early cancer diagnosis for patients without clear symptoms. The initiative, inspired by Denmark's diagnostic systems, focuses on reducing waiting times for diagnosis and treatment. Currently, only 35% of patients with concerning symptoms in the Cwm Taf area receive a timely diagnosis. The pilot involves 40 doctors in Cwm Cynon who can refer patients to a diagnostic center at the Royal Glamorgan Hospital within seven days, with the goal of diagnosing six patients per week. A similar clinic is planned for Neath Port Talbot Hospital. The scheme aims to streamline the diagnostic process, reduce delays, and improve survival rates by catching cancer earlier. If successful, the pilot could be expanded across the region.

England secured a dominant victory over Pakistan at Old Trafford, leveling the series with a day to spare. They posted 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared, achieving their second-largest win over Pakistan in terms of runs. Joe Root was named man of the match for his outstanding performance, scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second, along with taking four catches and a wicket. Captain Alastair Cook praised Root's responsibility and skill, while Root acknowledged improvements in his game after earlier mistakes. Pakistan struggled, with only Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq passing 50 in the series so far. Misbah expressed disappointment in their performance but remained hopeful for a turnaround. England's strong form suggests they will continue to dominate, with the next Test at Edgbaston starting on 3 August.

Warren Gatland is leading the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand, with Rob Howley as part of his backroom team. Robin McBryde, the forwards coach, will take on head coach responsibilities for Wales during the summer tour, a role he has held twice before. The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) is finalizing the appointment of assistant coaches to support McBryde. WRU officials, including chairman Gareth Davies, believe the involvement of Welsh coaches in the Lions tour and the summer tour will provide valuable development opportunities, benefiting Welsh rugby in the long term. The New Zealand tour is seen as a significant challenge that will inspire and test the coaches and players.

Charlie Austin's early penalty gave Southampton the lead against Hull City, who struggled initially and lost two key strikers, Abel Hernandez and Will Keane, to injuries in the first half. However, Hull's fortunes changed in the second half when Robert Snodgrass, coming off the bench, scored and then assisted Michael Dawson for a quick double, turning the game around. Despite Southampton's efforts to equalize, Hull's goalkeeper David Marshall made crucial saves, and Sam Clucas cleared a goal-bound shot off the line in added time, securing a 2-1 victory for Hull. This win ended Hull's six-game losing streak, though they remain in the relegation zone. Both managers reflected on the game, with Hull's Mike Phelan praising his team's resilience and Southampton's Claude Puel acknowledging a lack of concentration post-European competition. Hull next face Sunderland, while Southampton host Liverpool after the international break.

A fatal collision occurred at approximately 14:15 BST on the B1191 near Woodhall Spa, Lincolnshire, involving a motorcyclist and a tractor. The motorcyclist, a local resident, died in the crash, while the tractor driver was unharmed. Lincolnshire Police have requested witnesses to come forward and have closed the B1191 in both directions between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction and the A158 Jubilee Way junction in Horncastle.

The passage describes a political crisis in Macedonia triggered by covert recordings released since 2015, which allegedly reveal government corruption, vote-rigging, and cover-ups of crimes, including a murder. President Ivanov canceled an investigation into these claims, citing the need to "defend national interests" and end the turmoil ahead of early elections in June. His decision was criticized by opposition leader Zoran Zaev, who called it illegal and urged protests, and by EU officials, who warned it jeopardized Macedonia's EU membership aspirations. The government denies the allegations, accusing Zaev of destabilizing the country, while Zaev maintains the recordings expose high-level corruption. Protests erupted in Skopje following the announcement.

Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will manage Swansea's upcoming match against Bournemouth following Bob Bradley's dismissal. Swansea aims to appoint a new manager quickly, with Paul Clement being the top candidate. Curtis expressed concerns about the team's potential relegation, highlighting the challenges of returning to the Premier League from the Championship, citing examples like Norwich and Burnley. He reflected on Swansea's rise from financial struggles and near-relegation in 2003 to their promotion in 2011, noting a decline since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014. Curtis believes the team has lost its identity, the "Swansea Way," due to frequent managerial changes and player turnover. Despite this, he thinks the current squad is capable of avoiding relegation and emphasizes the importance of staying in the Premier League for the club and the local community.

Dagenham & Redbridge were relegated to the National League after a 3-2 defeat to Leyton Orient, despite goals from Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona. Armand Gnanduillet's winner sealed their fate, while Orient kept their play-off hopes alive, remaining two points behind the play-off spots. Dagenham, who reached League One in 2010, struggled defensively and offensively this season, with a poor goal difference and fewer goals scored compared to previous campaigns. Manager John Still, who returned for his third spell in December, expressed commitment to gaining promotion next season. Leyton Orient's interim manager Andy Hessenthaler emphasized professionalism and the importance of winning games to reach the play-offs, following the removal of player-manager Kevin Nolan earlier in the week.

Steven Gerrard, the former Liverpool captain and England skipper, is set to return to Liverpool as a youth coach in February, marking his first role since retiring as a player in November after a 19-year career. Gerrard, who won multiple trophies with Liverpool, including the Champions League and FA Cup, expressed his desire to become a manager in the future. Liverpool manager Jürgen Klopp praised Gerrard's potential, highlighting his playing experience and commitment to learning. Gerrard had previously been linked with a managerial role at MK Dons but felt it was too soon. He is currently working towards obtaining his Uefa A coaching licence, a requirement for managing in the Premier League.

McManus scored early to give Morton the lead, followed by a deflected strike from Ross Forbes to double their advantage. Kyle McAusland's goal brought Alloa back into the game before halftime. However, McManus scored again, and Denny Johnstone added a late goal, securing a comfortable win for Morton.

The passage highlights concerns raised by Ofsted about illegal schools operating in squalid and unsafe conditions, particularly in Birmingham and other areas in the Midlands, mainly within Muslim communities. Three such schools have been closed, and their owners are under investigation. Sir Michael Wilshaw, Chief Inspector of Schools in England, expressed serious concerns about the risk of child abuse and radicalization, describing the uncovered cases as the "tip of the iceberg." Ofsted has identified 18 unregulated schools during recent investigations. The government is consulting on stricter regulations for places teaching more than 6 to 8 hours a week and has funded a team to investigate illegal schools. Sir Michael criticized officials for providing confusing advice to proprietors and emphasized that the issue applies to all religious groups. The Education Secretary has asked Ofsted to prepare cases for prosecution and stressed the need for decisive action, with a consultation on further regulation open until mid-January.

Lilliard Gin, based at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh, is a small-scale gin distillery aiming to capture the local flavor of the Scottish Borders using regional botanicals. It operates from a small still in a cowshed, distinguishing it from other distilleries in development. The distillery is part of a broader initiative to establish the Scottish Borders as a region of distilling excellence, with plans for the area's first whisky distillery since 1837. Named after Lilliard, a legendary figure from the Battle of Ancrum Moor in 1545, the gin reflects the local landscape and the distillery's strong female production team. The project aligns with the ethos of local sourcing and complements the nearby Scottish Borders Brewery.

Harry Whitlam died in August 2013 after Gary Green, who was more than twice the legal alcohol limit, reversed a vehicle into him at Swithens Farm, Rothwell, near Leeds. Green had consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer before the incident. He was jailed for 16 months and two weeks after admitting to failing to ensure the safety of others, prosecuted under health and safety legislation since the accident occurred on private land. Harry's mother, Pam Whitlam, expressed the profound impact of the loss on her family, emphasizing the importance of not driving under the influence. The Health and Safety Executive described the case as tragic and Green's actions as reckless.

Luis Suárez, the Uruguayan striker, has been allowed to train and play in friendly matches following a ruling by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS). This decision partially lifts his ban, which was imposed after he bit Italy's Giorgio Chiellini during the 2014 World Cup. While Suárez can now participate in football-related activities, including training with his new club Barcelona and playing in friendlies, he remains banned from competitive matches for eight more games. His competitive debut for Barcelona is expected to be against Real Madrid on 26 October. Suárez's legal team argued that FIFA's initial ban was disproportionate, and CAS agreed that preventing him from training was excessive. However, the overall sanctions were largely upheld. Suárez will also be available for Uruguay's upcoming friendlies. The striker has a history of disciplinary issues, including previous bans for biting and racial abuse.

On 18 March 2014, Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a race in which competitors carried their partners over a 380-metre course featuring obstacles like haystacks, a steep slope, and water pistols. They defeated Vytautas Kirkliauskas and his wife, Neringa Kirliauskiene, from Lithuania. Richard credited their victory to a week of dedicated training. The event allowed various pairings, including men carrying women, men carrying men, and women carrying women. Rich and Anna will now compete at the World Championships in Finland in July.

The passage discusses the transition from a paper-based car tax disc system to an electronic system, set to take effect in October 2014. Stephen Hammond, a minister, addressed concerns about potential job losses at the DVLA (Driving and Vehicle Licensing Agency) in a letter to Swansea East AM Mike Hedges. Hammond assured that while job roles would change due to the new system, which allows for monthly direct debit payments, any reductions in staff numbers would be managed through redeployment rather than redundancies. Hedges welcomed the minister's assurances, noting that the changes would reduce job opportunities but also bring benefits like easier payment methods and the elimination of the need to display a tax disc. The minister's response aimed to provide comfort to DVLA employees concerned about their job security.

The passage discusses Hungary's stance on EU interference in its domestic policies, particularly regarding asylum seeker controls, a higher education law, and legislation targeting NGOs. Hungary's Foreign Minister, Péter Szijjártó, asserts that these issues fall under national competence and that Poland has pledged to veto any EU sanctions against Hungary. The EU objects to Hungary's restrictive measures, which include housing asylum seekers in shipping containers and a higher education law that threatens the Central European University (CEU), founded by George Soros. Additionally, proposed NGO legislation could label such organizations as "foreign-backed." Despite protests and EU pressure, Hungary remains firm on its policies, with no plans to backtrack. The EU has warned of potential action if no progress is made.

The passage announces the cast and production details for the live-action adaptation of *Beauty and the Beast*. Emma Watson will play Belle, Dan Stevens the Beast, and Luke Evans the villain Gaston. Kevin Kline is cast as Maurice, Belle's father, while Josh Gad will play Gaston's sidekick, LeFou. The film, directed by Bill Condon, begins filming in May at Shepperton Studios and is set for release in US cinemas on 17 March 2017.

Adrian Gill, a renowned journalist and columnist for *The Sunday Times*, passed away after being diagnosed with multiple cancers, which he humorously referred to as the "full English." Known for his wit, fearless writing, and unique style, Gill was celebrated as a "giant among journalists" and a central figure at the paper since 1993. Despite his illness, he remained stoical and continued writing, with his final column addressing his diagnosis set to be published posthumously. Gill's career was marked by both brilliance and controversy, with his provocative articles often sparking outrage. He overcame dyslexia to become a celebrated writer, contributing to various publications and earning widespread admiration from peers. Gill was married twice, including to current Home Secretary Amber Rudd, and was engaged to his long-term partner, Nicola Formby, at the time of his death. His legacy as a bold and influential journalist endures.

Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, a Mongolian rapper and lead singer of the band Khar Sarnai, was allegedly attacked during a performance in Ulan Bator. Reports indicate he was struck with a bottle and repeatedly kicked in the face, leaving him in a coma for about 10 days. The rapper had been wearing a traditional Mongolian robe embroidered with a swastika, a symbol in Mongolia that predates its association with Nazism. The Russian embassy is investigating the incident but has dismissed local press reports as "distorted." The suspected attacker, a Russian diplomatic officer, has not been arrested, with authorities stating the injury was not serious enough for detention and denying claims of diplomatic immunity influencing the decision. Sukhbaatar's family and lawyer have emphasized the cultural significance of the swastika in Mongolia and denied allegations that he shouted "Heil Hitler" during the show. The case remains under investigation.

The passage describes a protest by the action group Plane Stupid against an airport's expansion plans. The demonstrators staged the protest on the northern runway at 03:30 BST on Monday, leading to charges of aggravated trespass and entering a security-restricted area. They are scheduled to appear in court on 19 August. The Metropolitan Police mentioned that airport security would be reviewed following the incident.

Glamorgan's innings was highlighted by Nick Selman's second first-class century, scoring 101 off 144 balls, marking a return to form after a series of low scores. Seamers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles kept the pressure on, taking wickets regularly in cloudy conditions. Aneurin Donald contributed a quick 36, while Graham Wagg and Timm van der Gugten helped secure a bonus point. Gloucestershire struggled against Glamorgan's bowlers, ending the day evenly balanced. Selman reflected on his challenging season and the difficulty of opening in county cricket, expressing hope for continued success. Taylor acknowledged the challenging conditions for bowlers and expressed satisfaction with his performance, looking forward to the rest of the match.

Craig Hughes, 33, from Flint, was arrested by North Wales Police in August after making online threats to ambush and shoot police officers. He admitted to two charges at Mold Crown Court, where it was revealed he planned to falsely report a crime to lure officers to the Dee Estuary. Hughes, who was drunk during the threats, has a prior conviction for firearm possession. He was remanded in custody and will be sentenced next week. His legal team stated he had no intention of carrying out the threats or harming himself. The Hope Line Crisis Centre, which he contacted, provides confidential support to those in distress.

The passage describes a cricket match between Yorkshire and Surrey. Surrey posted a score of 255-7, with significant contributions from Davies and Ben Foakes, who shared a 130-run partnership. Yorkshire's chase was hindered by Stuart Meaker's three-wicket burst, which included key dismissals of Jonny Bairstow and Gary Ballance. Despite Tim Bresnan's 68, Yorkshire fell short, being all out for 236. Yorkshire aimed to reach Lord's for the first time since 2002 but were left to regret missed opportunities, including dropped catches. Surrey's Gareth Batty praised his team's performance, particularly the partnership between Davies and Foakes, while Yorkshire's Alex Lees expressed disappointment, acknowledging the team's failure to perform when it mattered most.

A 56ft converted trawler, located 6 miles west of South Stack, encountered flooding and contacted coastguards at 07:00 BST. The onboard pump was overwhelmed by the incoming water. The RNLI lifeboat crew provided an additional pump and towed the vessel to Holyhead.

Laura Muir, a 24-year-old middle-distance runner and veterinary medicine student, will miss the Commonwealth Games in April due to her final-year university exams in May. Despite her disappointment, she prioritizes completing her degree. Muir recently achieved a new outdoor personal best of 14:52.07 in the 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, finishing sixth, and fourth in the 1,500m. She remains optimistic about her future, aiming for at least two more Olympics and considering the World Indoor Championships in March as a potential target. Muir expressed pride in her performance and sees significant potential for her athletic career ahead.

In his BBC Sport column, Robbie Savage analyzes Liverpool's struggles to replicate last season's title challenge, attributing their decline to key issues such as the loss of Luis Suarez and Daniel Sturridge's injury, poor transfer decisions, and a lack of intensity and work-rate in their play. Liverpool's defense remains weak, and their set-piece effectiveness has dropped significantly. Savage suggests lineup changes for their upcoming match against Chelsea, emphasizing the need for improved midfield support and defensive solidity. He also discusses Steven Gerrard's ongoing physical and mental battle to maintain his performance level and secure his future at Liverpool, despite the lingering impact of his costly slip against Chelsea last season. Savage concludes that Liverpool are far from competing with top teams like Chelsea, who are currently in exceptional form.

A £45 million educational facility is planned for Sutherland Drive in Kilmarnock, featuring primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare center. East Ayrshire Council intends to name the campus after William McIlvanney, a renowned writer born and educated in Kilmarnock, pending approval from his family. McIlvanney, who was passionate about education, initially worked as an English teacher before becoming a full-time writer in 1975. He gained fame for his novels, including the Laidlaw trilogy, and was known as the "Godfather of Tartan Noir." McIlvanney also contributed to Scottish culture as a poet, journalist, broadcaster, and commentator on politics and sports. He passed away on December 5 at his Glasgow home.

A sea mine, believed to be a British mine from the 1940s or 1950s, was discovered near a swimming pool in Gourock, prompting the evacuation of three streets and the establishment of an exclusion zone on the river and at sea. Residents within 500 meters were advised to stay indoors and avoid going outside. Ferry services from Gourock and Rothesay experienced some disruption. Authorities emphasized the evacuation was precautionary, with no immediate danger to the community. Due to the mine's deterioration, it was moved to a safer location for disposal. Inverclyde Council thanked residents and businesses for their patience during the evacuation and safety procedures.

The passage discusses UK Sport's funding decisions for Olympic and Paralympic sports ahead of the Tokyo 2020 Games. A total of £345m will be invested in 31 sports, £2m less than the record £347m allocated for Rio 2016. Funding cuts have affected sports like archery, fencing, weightlifting, wheelchair rugby, and badminton, with cycling seeing a reduction of over £4m. Badminton England expressed shock at losing funding despite achieving a bronze medal in Rio. UK Sport has set Team GB a target of 51-85 Olympic and 115-162 Paralympic medals in Tokyo, aiming to maintain the success of Rio, where Britain won 67 Olympic and 147 Paralympic medals. Sports like judo, which met their targets, received slight funding increases. UK Sport emphasized prioritizing medal potential, while sports like basketball, handball, and volleyball criticized the lack of investment in team sports. New sports added to the Tokyo 2020 programme, such as baseball/softball and surfing, await funding confirmation. UK Sport has left £9m unallocated for further exploration of medal potential.

The passage describes a development plan in Bournemouth's East Cliff, where three Victorian hotels—Bay View Court, The Cottonwood, and the Ocean View—will be demolished to make way for a six-storey, four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks (nine and seven storeys tall). The project, led by The East Cliff Project LLP, includes a 90-room hotel and 122 assisted-living apartments. While the council approved the plan with a 7-3 vote, citing benefits to tourism and improved living for older residents, English Heritage and some residents objected, arguing the development would harm the conservation area's historic character. Despite 246 letters of support, 49 residents and the Ancient Monuments Society opposed the demolition, emphasizing the buildings' historical significance.

Pte Matthew Boyd, a 20-year-old soldier from the Royal Gibraltar Regiment, was fatally attacked by Jake Vallely while off-duty in Brecon on 8 May. Vallely, who had been drinking for seven hours and boasted about being the "hardest man in Brecon," punched and beat Boyd outside a bar called The Cellar. Vallely then dragged Boyd's unconscious body away before fleeing. Boyd, originally from Carrickfergus, County Antrim, was in Brecon for training exercises. Vallely, 24, was found guilty and will be sentenced on 8 December, while his friend Aaeron Evans was cleared of involvement as he had left before the attack. The incident, described as a "despicable act" by police, shocked the community. Boyd's family paid tribute to him as a loving, caring, and loyal individual with a promising future, expressing the profound loss and pain caused by his death. They highlighted the community's support, contrasting it with Vallely's claims of toughness.

Andrew Travers, the chief executive of Barnet Council, left his position by "mutual agreement" following an error that led to voters being turned away from all 155 polling stations in the borough due to missing names on the poll list. An independent investigation has been launched to examine the issue, with findings to be presented publicly by the end of May. The investigation will also assess arrangements for the upcoming EU Referendum. Deputy chief executive John Hooton will temporarily take over Travers' role. The council apologized for the disruption and offered emergency proxy votes to affected residents, but voters questioned the fairness of the election results. Travers, in a statement, blamed electoral registration lists for the problems and expressed confidence in the borough's future growth.

Gateshead defeated Wrexham 2-1 in a closely contested match. Josh Gillies opened the scoring for Gateshead with a fine free-kick, but Wrexham equalized before halftime through Sean Newton's set-piece. Ryan Bowman secured the win for Gateshead with a well-executed header from Craig Baxter's cross in the second half. Gateshead manager Malcolm Crosby praised his team's second-half performance and highlighted the quality of the winning goal. Wrexham manager Gary Mills expressed disappointment with his team's second-half performance, noting missed opportunities and defensive lapses. The match ended with Gateshead securing the victory.

The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 evaluates the social and economic well-being of individuals over 60 across 96 countries. Norway ranks highest, while Afghanistan is at the bottom, followed by Mozambique.

The passage describes the ambitious OneWeb project, which aims to deploy a global satellite network to provide broadband connectivity, especially to schools. Initially, the network will consist of at least 600 satellites, potentially expanding to over 2,000. Airbus, partnering with OneWeb, is revolutionizing satellite manufacturing by adopting high-volume, low-cost assembly line methods, similar to those used in car and plane production, to produce satellites at under $1 million each. The first assembly line has been established in Toulouse, France, with additional lines planned in Florida. The project requires an unprecedented rocket campaign, with over 20 Soyuz launches planned to deploy clusters of satellites. By the end of 2020, nearly 300 satellites are expected to be operational, increasing to over 600 a year later and over 800 by mid-decade. OneWeb has raised $1.7 billion in equity and is seeking further financing. The project also emphasizes debris mitigation, committing to de-orbit satellites within two years to prevent space junk. OneWeb, registered in the UK's Channel Islands, highlights the economic and regulatory benefits for the UK, positioning it as a leader in satellite constellation regulation. The initiative could disrupt the satellite industry, though not all spacecraft will require such

The passage discusses the financial pressures faced by the Scottish government due to UK government spending cuts. Mr. Swinney, a Scottish minister, highlighted that the UK government's spending review has placed significant pressure on Scotland's public expenditure, with a projected 12.5% real-term reduction in the Scottish government's discretionary budget by 2019-20 compared to 2010-11. He criticized the UK government's approach to reducing debt and deficit, stating that Scotland now faces tough financial choices. Despite these challenges, Mr. Swinney emphasized the Scottish government's commitment to protecting key priorities such as schools, hospitals, and police services. The UK government countered by stating that the Scottish government would have an additional £390m available next year, increasing to £750m with its own underspend, and highlighted the stability provided by the UK economy. Labour's public services spokeswoman, Jackie Baillie, criticized the Scottish government's approach, calling for a long-term budget and a real alternative to austerity.

The passage highlights the challenges faced by individuals with severe disabilities and their families due to the lack of suitable toilet facilities, known as Changing Places toilets, which are larger and equipped with additional features like hoists and benches. These facilities are crucial for those who require assistance from carers. Currently, there are 893 such toilets in the UK, but campaigners argue that this number is insufficient and are advocating for mandatory inclusion in building regulations for larger complexes like shopping centers and stadiums. The text shares personal stories from families affected by the absence of these facilities, emphasizing the emotional and practical difficulties they face. It also discusses the positive impact of existing Changing Places toilets and the efforts of organizations and businesses, like Arsenal Football Club, to accommodate these needs. The passage concludes by noting the importance of making these facilities compulsory to ensure accessibility for all.

A group of Italian consumer organizations has filed a formal antitrust complaint with the European Commission against McDonald's, accusing the company of imposing excessive rents and high fees on franchisees, which they claim restricts competition and leads to higher prices and reduced consumer choice. McDonald's defends its practices, stating that it shares risks and rewards with franchisees, a model it claims has been successful for years. The complaint is supported by unions, including the SEIU and European unions, who argue that McDonald's abuses its dominant market position, harming franchisees, workers, and consumers. The European Commission will review the complaint and may launch an investigation if the allegations are deemed credible. Franchisees operate 73% of McDonald's European restaurants, contributing significantly to the company's global revenues.

A social media campaign supporting 13-year-old Joshua Martin, who was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve, has gained global attention. The campaign, initiated by Bangor Elim Church where Josh's father is on staff, began with the hashtag #prayforjosh on Facebook and Instagram. The campaign went viral, with a post being shared 948 times and viewed by over 79,000 people. A mystery donor funded a billboard with the hashtag near Holywood, further amplifying the campaign. Josh, a pupil at Bangor Grammar, has received widespread support from his classmates and people worldwide as he undergoes treatment.

The UK government has announced plans to close Brecon Barracks, a historic military site in Wales that has been operational since 1805. The decision has been strongly criticized by Brecon and Radnorshire MP Chris Davies, who highlighted the barracks' long history and its role in every major conflict since the 19th century. Davies condemned the closure as disrespectful to this legacy and launched a petition against it, expressing concerns about the impact on local unemployment and the town's military tourism industry. The barracks employs 85 civilian staff and 90 military personnel, but jobs are not thought to be at risk. Nearby military facilities, such as the Sennybridge training ground and Dering Lines infantry school, will remain unaffected. The reorganization includes creating a specialist light infantry center at St Athan and closing Cawdor Barracks by 2024 and a Sennybridge storage depot by 2025. Labour's Shadow Defence Secretary, Nia Griffith, supported restructuring but warned of the uncertainty and impact on livelihoods caused by base closures.

The passage discusses the implications of Brexit on the UK fishing industry, highlighting both risks and opportunities. It notes that while many in the fishing community supported Brexit to regain control over UK waters and potentially become a leading fish-exporting nation like Norway, the industry faces challenges. The UK fishing industry contributes a small fraction to GDP and employs few people, which might make it a low priority in Brexit negotiations. However, the House of Lords warns against marginalizing the industry, given its cultural and economic significance to coastal communities.

The EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) has been unpopular in the UK, but post-Brexit, the UK may need to allow EU boats access to UK waters to maintain market access for UK fish exports to the EU. The report suggests retaining some elements of the CFP, such as quotas based on scientific advice, and emphasizes the need for continued cooperation with neighboring states. Brexit could lead to different fisheries management regimes across the UK, complicating the situation. Despite these challenges, the industry remains optimistic about the opportunities Brexit may bring, such as better control over fishing quotas and sustainable management. The UK government has expressed a commitment to ensuring British companies can trade freely in the single market while also reviewing fisheries management for sustainability and fairness

Ed Snowden, a former CIA technical worker, revealed himself as the source of leaks exposing extensive U.S. government surveillance programs. The leaks, described as "extremely damaging" by U.S. officials, disclosed that the National Security Agency (NSA) had access to vast amounts of personal data, including chat logs, phone records, and social media activity, through programs like Prism. Prism allegedly provided "backdoor" access to servers of major tech companies like Google, Facebook, and Apple, though these companies denied involvement. The U.S. government defended the surveillance as necessary for national security, while critics questioned its scope and legality. Data protection laws vary by country, but U.S. laws, such as the Patriot Act, allow authorities to access data stored abroad, raising concerns about privacy and jurisdiction. The EU expressed concern over the implications for its citizens, while UK officials remained ambiguous about their involvement. Snowden justified his actions as a stand against invasive surveillance, emphasizing the importance of privacy in a digital age.

The passage discusses OpenAI, a venture backed by prominent figures and companies like Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys, and Amazon Web Services. OpenAI aims to advance artificial intelligence (AI) research with a focus on benefiting humanity, free from financial obligations. While some experts, including Elon Musk and Stephen Hawking, have warned about the potential existential threats posed by AI, others believe such risks are remote. OpenAI emphasizes the importance of developing AI in a way that benefits society broadly and safely, ensuring it aligns with human values. The venture has pledged $1 billion, with only a small portion to be spent in the near future.

L/Bdr Ben Parkinson, a British soldier seriously injured in a 2006 bomb attack in Afghanistan, carried the Olympic torch on 26 June. Despite losing his speech due to a brain injury, he has regained the ability to speak and remains determined, spending 12 hours daily in gym and rehab while supporting military charities. His participation in the torch relay garnered immense public support, with over 5,000 Facebook friend requests and 19,000 hits on his page. His mother noted the overwhelming response, including increased mail and email traffic, and numerous requests for him to visit places with the torch. Facebook suggested he consider a public page or subscription feature due to his popularity. The Olympic torch relay involves 8,000 people over 70 days, culminating in the London Games' opening ceremony on 27 July.

In 2011, the U.S. poverty rate remained at 15%, with 46.2 million Americans in poverty, following three years of increases. The real median household income decreased by 1.5%, and the poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021. Income inequality, measured by the Gini index, rose by 1.6%, marking the first annual increase since 1993. The percentage of uninsured Americans dropped to 15.7% from 16.3%. Poverty had peaked at 15.1% in 2010.

Jos Buttler, a 25-year-old cricketer, joined Lancashire from Somerset in 2013 and has signed a contract extension keeping him at the club until 2019. Known for his prowess in short-format cricket, Buttler holds the record for England's three fastest ODI centuries, including a 46-ball century against Pakistan. Ashley Giles, the cricket director and head coach, praised Buttler as one of the most talented cricketers, highlighting his crucial role in Lancashire's T20 Blast victory last year and his positive influence in the team. Buttler, who has been playing for Mumbai Indians in the Indian Premier League, is set to return to Lancashire for a T20 Blast match against Durham.

The decommissioned Type 22 frigates HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham, and HMS Cornwall are moored in Portsmouth Harbour, with no preservation proposals submitted. Bidders are finalizing their bids, and a decision is expected in spring. The UK government aims to award at least one frigate to a UK ship recycler to assess the industry's capacity. Penny Mordaunt, MP for Portsmouth North, supports UK recyclers but hopes at least one ship can be repurposed, possibly as a reef and diving attraction for tourism. The Ministry of Defence seeks the best financial return for taxpayers, considering all options. Originally anti-submarine ships, Type 22 frigates evolved into versatile combatants with advanced command and communication facilities, crewed by about 280. Last year, HMS Ark Royal was sold for scrap for £3 million.

Since 1987, Fiji has experienced significant racial and political tensions, primarily between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians, leading to instability and international isolation. A coup in 1987 overthrew an Indian-dominated government, followed by another in 2000 that saw the country's first ethnic Indian prime minister and others held hostage. These events damaged Fiji's economy, particularly tourism, and its international reputation. A 2006 military coup and Fiji's suspension from the Commonwealth in 2009 due to a lack of democratic progress further exacerbated the situation. Free elections in 2014 led to the restoration of diplomatic ties with Australia and New Zealand and Fiji's re-instatement in the Commonwealth. The population is divided between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians, with minimal mixing and deep informal segregation. Fiji's economy relies on sugar, tourism, mining, and services but suffers from trade and budget deficits, making it a major per capita recipient of international aid.

Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad stated that Syria is committed to complying with the timetable to destroy its chemical weapons, despite missing a recent deadline. He reported that a shipment of weapons was attacked twice by terrorist groups while being transported from Damascus to Latakia. Mekdad criticized US Secretary of State John Kerry's condemnation of Syria's use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, denying that civilians were targeted and accusing the US of supporting terrorist elements. Meanwhile, human rights groups reported significant civilian casualties from barrel bomb attacks in Aleppo. The Syrian government denied reports that rebels had seized most of Aleppo's central prison, though conflicting accounts suggest ongoing fighting and rebel control. Syria has declared 1,300 tonnes of chemical weapons, with only 4% removed so far. The US expressed concern over delays, and Russia urged Syria to complete the transfer by March 1. The OPCW acknowledged security concerns have slowed the process, but Mekdad reaffirmed Syria's commitment to fulfilling its obligations.

The passage discusses the 2014 Booker Prize shortlist, highlighting key details about the nominated authors and their works. Neel Mukherjee's *The Lives of Others*, set in 1960s Calcutta, is the 5/2 favorite to win. The prize is now open to all English-language authors, regardless of nationality. The shortlist includes three British writers (Howard Jacobson, Ali Smith, and Joshua Ferris), two Americans (Karen Joy Fowler and Joshua Ferris), and one Australian (Richard Flanagan). Jacobson's *J* explores a dystopian world, while Smith's *How To Be Both* offers two interlinked stories. Fowler's *We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves* is the best-selling book on the list. The winner will be announced at London's Guildhall, with each shortlisted author receiving £2,500. The judging panel is chaired by AC Grayling, and the ceremony will be covered by the BBC. The passage also notes debates about the prize's criteria and the impact of the shortlist on book sales.

A man, referred to as PJS, is appealing against a Court of Appeal ruling that lifted a ban on his identification in the media in England and Wales. The Supreme Court will now consider whether to grant an appeal and decide its outcome. An interim injunction preventing his identification remains in place until the hearing concludes. PJS, who has young children and a spouse in the public eye, argues for his right to privacy, while *The Sun on Sunday* seeks to publish allegations of his extra-marital activities. The case involves claims of sexual encounters with another individual, AB, and a three-way encounter involving AB's partner, CD. Despite efforts to maintain confidentiality, details have spread widely online and in other jurisdictions, leading the Court of Appeal to conclude that a permanent injunction is unlikely. The judges ruled that confidentiality has "probably been lost" due to the widespread dissemination of the story.

Fosse Park, located near junction 21 of the M1 and opened in 1989, was purchased for £345.5 million in August. The new owners are preparing plans to address parking and traffic congestion issues, as well as improve the appearance of the units. Ernie White, leader of Blaby District Council, mentioned that the new owners have engaged with the council to resolve potential planning questions, viewing Fosse Park as a key gateway and investment opportunity. Paul Clarke, director of investments at Crown Estates, emphasized the need to enhance the quality of common areas, including parking and walking spaces, to ensure Fosse Park reaches its full potential.

The live-action remake of *Beauty and the Beast* sparked controversy in Malaysia due to its inclusion of a "gay moment," leading to a delay in its release as the Malaysian Censorship Board (LPF) reviewed the content. While the LPF approved the film with a minor edit to the gay scene, a new release date has not been announced. Homosexuality is illegal in Malaysia, and the decision to review the film drew criticism from netizens, who called it unnecessary. The film received a "P13 parental guidance classification," and local cinemas are offering refunds for pre-purchased tickets. The "gay moment" involves LeFou, Gaston's sidekick, grappling with his feelings for Gaston. Malaysia's tourism minister criticized the ban as "ridiculous."

Landlords in Southampton who rent properties to more than three unrelated individuals must obtain a House of Multiple Occupation (HMO) licence, which costs around £1,000. However, many landlords avoid applying despite facing fines of up to £20,000. Southampton City Council estimates there are 1,500 unlicensed HMOs in the area. Tenants in unlicensed HMOs often face issues such as fear of eviction and poor living conditions due to the lack of regulation. Nationally, mandatory HMO licensing applies to properties with three or more storeys and five or more unrelated occupants. In Southampton, specific areas are subject to HMO licensing under two designations introduced in 2013 and 2015. While most landlords comply, a small minority resist, leading to prosecutions against one firm and 13 individuals.

Acting Taoiseach Enda Kenny (Fine Gael) and Micheál Martin (Fianna Fáil) aim to avoid a second election. Fianna Fáil has agreed to facilitate a minority government but will not support its program. A key issue is water charges, with Fianna Fáil advocating for their immediate removal and Fine Gael supporting their retention. A commission to review Irish Water's future is under consideration. After the election, Fine Gael holds 50 seats, Fianna Fáil 44, Sinn Féin 23, and Labour 7, but no party secured a majority, and a taoiseach has yet to be elected.

The Sorrento, a ferry owned by Italian company Atlantica di Navigazione, caught fire on a car deck while traveling to Valencia, approximately 27km from Mallorca. The blaze quickly escalated, leading to the evacuation of passengers and crew onto lifeboats. At least three people were injured, with one seriously hurt, and were airlifted to hospital. The passengers were rescued by another ship, the Puglia, and were en route to Palma de Mallorca. Spanish officials arranged for psychologists to provide counselling upon their arrival. The fire's cause remains unclear, and the ship is at risk of sinking. The incident began on Tuesday afternoon, with distress signals sent at 13:50 local time. Initially, the captain did not anticipate abandoning the ship, but the intensity of the fire necessitated a full evacuation.

The Electoral Commission reported concerns over duplicate voter registrations, with 38 MPs highlighting instances of potential double voting, a criminal offense. A record 46.8 million people were registered for the 8 June election, with a 68.7% turnout, the highest since 1997. Despite a surge in voter registration applications (2.9 million over six weeks), duplicate applications remain a significant issue, with estimates ranging from 30% to 70% in different areas. The lack of integration between local electoral registers and the online registration system exacerbates the problem, causing administrative and financial burdens. The Commission recommends clearer registration site information and a verification function, similar to systems in Australia, New Zealand, and Ireland. Labour warned against measures that could hinder young people and students from registering, emphasizing the need for balanced solutions. The Commission also stressed the illegality of voting twice in general elections and called for better cross-checking of electoral registers to prevent double voting.

Lawrence Phillips, a former NFL player and University of Nebraska star, died by suicide at age 40. Phillips played for the St. Louis Rams, Miami Dolphins, and San Francisco 49ers in the 1990s but faced numerous legal and personal issues, including convictions for assaulting a former girlfriend and driving into a group of teenagers. He was serving a 30-year prison sentence and was recently accused of killing his cellmate. A judge found sufficient evidence to try him for the cellmate's death. His former coach, Tom Osborne, described him as intelligent but troubled by anger and personal struggles.

Private Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram and official mascot of the Mercian Regiment, was promoted to lance corporal at an event in Chester celebrating the regiment's eighth anniversary. The promotion, awarded by Brigadier Andrew Williams, recognized his "good behaviour." As the 30th mascot ram in a tradition dating back to the mid-19th century, Lance Corporal Derby XXX joined the regiment in 2014, has an army number, receives rations, and takes holidays during mating season. He has participated in public events, including switching on Christmas lights and meeting Prince William at a memorial unveiling.

Liverpool secured a dramatic 4-3 victory over Borussia Dortmund in the Europa League quarter-final, with Dejan Lovren scoring a last-minute winner. The match, filled with emotion and excitement, showcased Liverpool's resilience under manager Jurgen Klopp, who inspired his team to overcome a 2-0 deficit and later a 3-1 disadvantage. Goals from Philippe Coutinho, Mamadou Sakho, and Divock Origi, alongside Lovren's decisive header, highlighted Liverpool's fighting spirit. The victory, reminiscent of their 2005 Champions League comeback, moved Liverpool closer to a potential Europa League title and a return to the Champions League. Klopp's impact on the team and fans was evident, as he transformed doubters into believers, emphasizing determination and unity. The match also featured a poignant tribute to the Hillsborough disaster victims, adding to the emotional atmosphere at Anfield.
