McNeil, a long-serving Labour MSP, highlighted the need for Holyrood to learn from Westminster's committee system to ensure accountability and scrutiny. Goldie, a former Conservative MSP, humorously noted she would miss interactions with Finance Secretary John Swinney. Marwick expressed gratitude for Salmond's contributions and was moved by McNeil's speech. The speeches underscored the honor of serving in the Scottish Parliament and the ongoing journey of Scottish governance.

The passage announces the cast and production details for the live-action adaptation of *Beauty and the Beast*. Emma Watson will play Belle, Dan Stevens the Beast, and Luke Evans as Gaston. Kevin Kline is cast as Maurice, and Josh Gad will play LeFou. The film, directed by Bill Condon, begins filming in May 2016 at Shepperton Studios and is set for release in US cinemas on 17 March 2017.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) will announce its decisions on potential charges related to the 1989 Hillsborough disaster, where 96 football fans were unlawfully killed, during a private meeting with victims' relatives at 11:00 BST. The meeting, led by Sue Hemming of the CPS, will address evidence files for 23 suspects, including 15 from Operation Resolve (investigating the disaster's causes) and eight from a probe into police conduct. Margaret Aspinall, whose son died in the tragedy, expressed hope for accountability and closure, acknowledging the long struggle faced by the families. The relatives remain determined to seek justice, emphasizing their desire for accountability above all else.

Chelmsford Prison has reported multiple incidents of packages being thrown over its walls, with a former inmate describing the facility as "notorious" for being inundated with mobile phones and synthetic cannabis. A local resident witnessed such incidents four times in two weeks, expressing concern but not fear. The Ministry of Justice acknowledged the efforts of prison staff to prevent contraband but emphasized the need for additional measures. The Justice Secretary has requested a review of tools to address the issue. While the former inmate mentioned drones being used to deliver contraband, the Ministry of Justice stated there is no evidence of drones at Chelmsford. New laws now impose up to two years in prison for smuggling packages into prisons.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, suffered serious head injuries after being struck by Brian Wright's car outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December. Wright, 55, admitted to hitting Blackburn but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving, claiming he was blinded by the setting sun. Blackburn, a beloved figure who had worked as a lollipop lady for 20 years, is now in residential care. Wright expressed deep remorse for the incident, which occurred when he failed to stop at a red light while Blackburn was escorting a woman and her child across the road. The trial is ongoing.

Laura Muir, a 24-year-old middle-distance runner and veterinary medicine student, will miss the Commonwealth Games in April due to her final-year university exams in May. Despite her disappointment, she prioritizes completing her degree. Muir, who finished fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, expressed optimism about future opportunities, including the World Indoor Championships in March and potential participation in two to three more Olympics. She recently set a new outdoor personal best of 14:52.07 in the 5,000m and remains hopeful about her athletic future.

Trevor Deely, a 22-year-old man from County Kildare, Ireland, disappeared in December 2000 after attending a Christmas party. He was last seen on CCTV footage talking to a man dressed in black outside the Bank of Ireland on Baggot Street, where he worked, before heading to Haddington Road. The footage, enhanced using specialist technology, shows the same man following Deely. Despite releasing the footage in April and appealing for the man to come forward, he remains unidentified. A recent search in Chapelizod, Dublin, involving excavations, began as part of an ongoing investigation into Deely's disappearance, which is being reviewed by a team of detectives.

Juan Martín del Potro, ranked 165th after a two-year injury hiatus, defeated Stan Wawrinka in a hard-fought match (3-6, 6-3, 7-6, 6-3) at Wimbledon. Del Potro, a former US Open champion and world number four, is playing his first Grand Slam since 2014 after recovering from multiple wrist surgeries. He expressed joy at his comeback and the crowd's support. In the same tournament, Nick Kyrgios overcame Dustin Brown in a rain-affected five-set match (6-7, 6-1, 2-6, 6-4, 6-4) and will face Feliciano Lopez in the next round. Other notable victories included Tomas Berdych and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga advancing comfortably. Del Potro, Kyrgios, and Andy Murray are in the same half of the draw, potentially setting up key matchups later in the tournament.

Tunisia faced potential expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations after lodging complaints against the Confederation of African Football (Caf) following a controversial quarter-final loss to Equatorial Guinea in 2015. Tunisia accused the referee of poor decisions but denied allegations of corruption. After a meeting with Caf president Issa Hayatou, Tunisia apologized, resolving the dispute and securing their participation in the 2017 tournament. Meanwhile, Morocco, initially banned and fined $1 million for refusing to host the 2015 Nations Cup due to Ebola concerns, had their ban overturned by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) and their fine reduced to $50,000, allowing them to enter the 2017 qualifiers. Both nations are now set to compete in the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations, with Tunisia aiming for a record 13th consecutive appearance.

McLaren, a historically dominant Formula 1 team with 182 grand prix wins, 12 drivers' championships, and 8 constructors' titles, is currently struggling despite having two world champions, including Fernando Alonso, in their lineup. The team's decline began in 2013 due to chassis design issues, and while they have improved their car, their performance is hindered by Honda's underperforming power unit. This is a stark contrast to their golden era with Honda in the late 1980s, when they dominated with drivers like Ayrton Senna and Alain Prost. McLaren has experienced cycles of success and decline throughout its history, with notable periods of dominance in the 1980s and late 1990s. Recent years have been marred by scandals, such as the 2007 "Spygate" and 2009 "lie-gate," and a lack of championships since 2008. Team principal Ron Dennis believes McLaren will eventually break Mercedes' dominance and return to winning titles, but for now, the team relies on belief and progress to restore its reputation and achieve future success.

On 6 October 2014, paramedics responded to a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST. Police found several people still at the bar, and till receipts indicated alcohol was served until 04:49 BST, outside licensing hours. Colleen O'Neill, the 43-year-old license holder, and James Thomas, 44, both of Kevin Lynch Park, were charged with allowing liquor consumption outside permitted hours. The judge ordered the bar's closure for three months, citing O'Neill's "appalling record" and expressing concern over the lack of authority to impose a custodial sentence. O'Neill was fined £3,000, and Thomas was fined £1,000. The defence solicitor acknowledged that licensing laws were not strictly followed and that the bar had been improperly managed.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for most three-pointers in a season, scoring 45 points and hitting eight three-pointers to surpass his previous record of 272. His performance helped the Golden State Warriors overcome a 13-point deficit to defeat the Portland Trail Blazers 116-105. Klay Thompson contributed 26 points, and the Warriors avoided their first three-game losing streak of the season. Meanwhile, the Chicago Bulls staged a remarkable comeback, erasing a 19-point halftime deficit to beat the Miami Heat 89-78. Pau Gasol led the Bulls with 16 points and 15 rebounds, while Miami struggled, being outscored 57-27 in the second half. The Bulls moved back into the No. 3 spot in the Eastern Conference standings.

The passage describes an encounter between Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic with YouTube star Bas van Velzen at Melwood. Initially, the players believed van Velzen was a competition winner who had won the chance to meet them and receive a free-kick masterclass. However, it soon became evident that van Velzen was no ordinary fan, as he demonstrated impressive free-kick skills, even scoring a top-corner strike that left the stand-in keeper helpless. Balotelli also showcased his own free-kick ability. Van Velzen, known for his YouTube videos of free-kick exploits, expressed his joy at meeting the players and pretending to be less skilled initially. He also surprised Balotelli by referencing the player's infamous slogan. The experience was a dream come true for van Velzen, who enjoyed interacting with his football idols.

The passage discusses how women carrying the BRCA1 gene mutation, like Angelina Jolie, can significantly reduce their risk of dying from breast cancer by undergoing an oophorectomy (removal of the ovaries). A Canadian study of 676 breast cancer patients with BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutations found that oophorectomy reduced the risk of breast cancer death by 62% in BRCA1 carriers, though not in BRCA2 carriers. The procedure also led to a 65% reduction in death from all causes. The study highlights that oophorectomy is most effective when performed soon after diagnosis, with a 73% reduction in death for BRCA1 carriers who had the surgery within two years. The protective effect lasts up to 15 years. The findings suggest oophorectomy should be considered as part of treatment discussions for BRCA mutation carriers with early-stage breast cancer. BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutations significantly increase lifetime breast cancer risk (50-80%) and ovarian cancer risk. Genetic testing is available for these mutations, which are more common in Ashkenazi Jewish women. Jolie, who underwent both a double mastectomy and oophorectomy, shared that the procedures did not diminish her sense of femininity.

A married couple, Derek Lowe, 38, and Tina Lowe, 33, were struck and killed by an Amtrak train on Easter morning in Durham, North Carolina. The accident occurred shortly before 10 a.m. on property owned by Norfolk-Southern. The train, No. 80, the Carolinian, was traveling from Charlotte to New York City. None of the 166 passengers were injured, although a man who fell ill during the delay received treatment. The train was delayed for about two hours and 45 minutes before continuing its journey. The Lowes, who may have lived in a homeless camp, were pronounced dead at the scene. A man who knew them described their struggles and urged kindness towards those in difficult situations. Durham is located about 25 miles northwest of Raleigh, the train's next destination. The trip from Charlotte to New York City typically takes about 13 hours and 30 minutes.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former mid-level member of the Medellin Cartel, fled Colombia in the 1980s after a confrontation with his boss. He later became a key informant for the DEA, providing crucial information that led to the prosecution of high-profile figures like Carlos Lehder Rivas and former Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega. Toro worked undercover for 27 years without pay, relying on the promise of U.S. citizenship as his reward. However, after retiring due to declining health, he faces deportation as the DEA has not fulfilled its promise. Toro, now living illegally in the U.S., fears for his life if deported to Colombia, where he believes he would be killed. Despite his significant contributions, the DEA has refused to assist him, leaving him in legal and financial limbo. A former colleague provided $5,000 for an operation, but Toro remains unable to secure a green card, passport, or social security benefits. His temporary visa expired, and he is prepared to go into hiding if necessary. Toro seeks only the citizenship he was promised, stating he has atoned for his past mistakes.

The U.S. body regulating internet addresses, ICANN, is investigating Canadian company Vox Populi Registry Ltd. for its use of the '.sucks' domain name, which has been used to charge high fees from celebrities like Kevin Spacey and companies to protect their reputations. Major brands such as YouTube, Bing, Visa, and Bank of America have also been targeted. ICANN is seeking to determine if Vox Populi's actions are illegal and may take action if regulators find them in breach of contract. The company charges $2,499 annually for these domains, with resellers offering them for around $2,000. Critics, including an advisory panel, have labeled the practice as predatory and coercive.

A baby boy's body was found in 1988 floating in a pond in Weasenham St Peter, Norfolk, wrapped in a blanket inside a Sainsbury's bag. The case remained unsolved for 27 years until a periodic review led to the exhumation of the body in 2021. DNA analysis identified the mother, who admitted to concealing her pregnancy and delivering a stillborn baby. She explained that she placed the baby in the pond shortly before it was discovered. The mother was arrested on suspicion of infanticide, but the charge was dropped after she provided details only the mother would know. Police ruled out foul play, and the baby, now named Peter after the local church, was reburied. A support group funded a new headstone, and the case was finally closed, bringing a long-standing mystery to an end.

A taxi driver, Michael Young, has been ordered to pay compensation to Kristopher Hicks, a passenger who suffered severe brain injuries after jumping out of the moving taxi. The incident occurred five years ago when Young mistakenly believed Hicks intended to evade paying the fare and decided to drive him back to the taxi rank as a lesson. Hicks objected and eventually jumped from the vehicle while it was moving at over 20mph, resulting in life-altering injuries, including epilepsy and the need for round-the-clock care. The High Court ruled that Young unlawfully imprisoned Hicks, entitling him to damages, though the compensation amount will be around 50% of the family's request, potentially amounting to hundreds of thousands of pounds. The judge acknowledged the driver's intent was not malicious but emphasized the dangerous nature of his actions. Hicks' injuries have left him dependent on his mother for care, and both parties have the right to appeal the decision.

On Wednesday night, tornado sirens sounded in Kansas as severe storms brought reports of tornadoes. A tornado was spotted near Goddard, west of Wichita, moving northeast and posing risks to nearby communities. Severe weather expert Chad Myers warned of ongoing storms and the heightened danger of nighttime tornadoes. Additional tornado sightings were reported in southwestern Kansas, near Aetna. The storms also affected Missouri, with potential tornado activity in Potosi, causing wind damage, flooding, and structural damage. Social media posts documented fallen trees, damaged roofs, and large hail. More storms were forecasted for Thursday across the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the southern Great Lakes.

Luke Rockhold and Lyoto Machida are set to face off in a middleweight fight in New Jersey. Rockhold, aiming for his fourth consecutive win, plans to dominate Machida by being aggressive and cutting off Machida's evasive tactics. He believes Machida has limited chances to win on the feet and even less on the ground. Rockhold respects Machida's skills but is confident in his own abilities and preparation, including daily marathons to ensure he can chase Machida down. Machida, coming off a recent victory, is also confident, believing his technique and strategy can secure him a win and a title shot. Both fighters acknowledge mutual respect but are determined to showcase their styles and secure victory.

A light general aviation aircraft, an Aerostar plane, touched down at Aero Acres Residential Airpark in Fort Pierce, Florida, without deploying its landing gear, skidding along the runway on its belly. The incident, captured on video, shows the plane approaching normally but landing with a bump, causing its propellers to ricochet off the ground and its wings to bounce. The pilot, realizing the mistake, re-engaged the engines and took off again, despite damage to the propellers. The pilot, 85-year-old Chris Georgaklis, managed to fly 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale and land safely. The incident, likely caused by human error or mechanical failure, is under investigation by the FAA.

Manchester City manager Manuel Pellegrini has expressed disappointment in midfielder Yaya Touré's performance this season but has pledged to support him until the end of the season. Despite criticism and reports that City will consider offers for Touré in the summer as part of a squad overhaul, Pellegrini dismissed suggestions that Touré needs a rest. The team has struggled recently, earning only 18 points from their last 13 games, and faces West Ham without captain Vincent Kompany due to injury. Goalkeeper Joe Hart acknowledged the players' responsibility for underperformance but affirmed Pellegrini's support within the squad. Meanwhile, West Ham manager Sam Allardyce has cautioned left-back Aaron Cresswell against moving to City, citing examples of other English players who struggled for playing time after similar moves.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian mafia fugitive known as the "Godfather of Uxbridge," will be allowed to remain in the UK after his seven-year prison sentence, issued by an Italian court in 1999 for his involvement with the Cosa Nostra, was dropped. Rancadore, who has lived in Britain for over 20 years, had been fighting extradition since his arrest in 2013. However, his sentence expired in October 2014 under Italian law, which extinguishes a sentence after more than double the penalty time has passed. The Italian Court of Appeal agreed to nullify the conviction, and the European arrest warrant is set to be withdrawn. Rancadore's solicitor expressed confidence that he would be discharged from the proceedings, allowing him to live peacefully in England with his family. The case has drawn criticism for the time and resources spent, with legal experts questioning the efficiency of the extradition process. The Crown Prosecution Service acknowledged a procedural error but denied it significantly impacted the outcome. Rancadore, who lived under the alias Marc Skinner, was convicted in absentia for mafia association and taking bribes in Palermo. His extradition was initially denied due

Mr. Mole, ridden by AP McCoy, is one of three 7-2 co-favourites in the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday, alongside Special Tiara and Sprinter Sacre. This race marks McCoy's final ride in a Grade One event before his retirement. Sprinter Sacre will be ridden by Nico de Boinville due to Barry Geraghty's injury. McCoy's full schedule for his last day as a professional jockey will be confirmed on Friday. The race also includes other runners such as Somersby, trained by Mick Channon.

Virginia Trimble Ritter, the mother of Marcia Trimble, who was raped and murdered in 1975, recently viewed crime scene photos of her daughter's body for the first time, expressing a desire for revenge. Marcia's body was found 33 days after she disappeared, and Ritter's then-husband had advised her against seeing the body or photos. Decades later, Ritter decided to view the photos, despite warnings from the lead investigator. Jerome Sydney Barrett, the perpetrator, was convicted in 2009 and sentenced to 44 years for the crime. The case remained unsolved for 33 years until DNA evidence linked Barrett to the murder. Ritter described the traumatic details of the photos, revealing the extent of Marcia's injuries and her emotional reaction. Barrett had a history of sex crimes and was linked to another murder in 1975.

Rory McIlroy is determined to win the Masters to complete his career Grand Slam, a feat achieved by only five other golfers. He views his 2011 final-round collapse at Augusta as a pivotal moment in his career, teaching him valuable lessons that helped him win subsequent majors. McIlroy, who has one top-10 finish in six Masters appearances, believes winning at Augusta is a "career-long goal" and considers it "unthinkable" not to win the green jacket at least once. He aims to use the golf course as a sanctuary from external pressures and hopes to secure his first Masters victory, potentially leading to multiple wins at Augusta.

The passage highlights several trending stories from the week. Key events include the appearance of four rainbows in the New York area after heavy rain, captured by Amanda Curtis, CEO of a fashion company. In rural China, hiring exotic dancers for wakes is becoming common but faces a crackdown. Robert Downey Jr. grew agitated during a UK interview about his private life. A new trend, the #KylieJennerChallenge, involves lip plumping by sucking on a jar. A 102-year-old woman, Alice Barker, revisited her past with filmmakers' help. A prom-posal referencing bombs sparked controversy over racism accusations. Ewan McGregor is set to play Lumiere in *Beauty and the Beast*, and Johnny Depp's transformation in the *Black Mass* trailer drew attention. A pregnancy announcement referencing *The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air* and a military dad photobombing his son also trended.

The passage highlights the alarming impact of foetal alcohol syndrome (FAS) in England, with 272 children hospitalised in the past year due to disabilities caused by prenatal alcohol exposure. Experts warn that the actual number affected could be much higher, with World Health Organisation research suggesting at least 1 in 100 UK babies may suffer learning, behavioural, and physical problems from alcohol exposure in the womb, equating to around 7,500 cases annually. FAS is described as a lifelong condition with no cure, and it is under-diagnosed. The story of 15-year-old Niamh Brown, who has FAS and requires constant care, illustrates the severe consequences. Other health issues linked to prenatal alcohol exposure include liver, kidney, and heart problems, cerebral palsy, sight loss, and epilepsy. While current government advice allows limited alcohol consumption during pregnancy, experts advocate for a complete abstinence recommendation to prevent FAS.

Shaun Andrew McKerry, a 31-year-old ex-juvenile offender with a history of repeated crimes, was jailed for six years after attempting to rob Shildon Post Office and Stores in County Durham on March 15. Armed with an axe, McKerry demanded cash but was tackled by the shop owner, Sab Dhillon, and struck twice with a baseball bat by Dhillon's wife, Sam, which disarmed him. The incident was captured on camera, and McKerry was arrested when police arrived. Known as "Boomerang Boy" for his habit of returning home after crimes, McKerry has a lengthy criminal record, including shoplifting, burglary, and other offenses dating back to his youth.

Four Royal Navy sailors—Joshua Finbow (23), Simon Radford (31), Craig Stoner (24), and Darren Smalley (35)—have been charged with the gang rape of a young woman in her early 20s at an alcohol-fueled party at a Canadian barracks in Halifax, Nova Scotia. The alleged assault occurred on April 10 after the sailors, who were in Canada for a Royal Navy ice hockey tournament, returned to the barracks. The four men appeared in court in Dartmouth, Nova Scotia, where they were granted bail under strict conditions, including surrendering their passports, residing at the Stadacona Naval Base in Halifax, and remaining employed by the Royal Navy. They are prohibited from contacting the victim or six witnesses and cannot leave Nova Scotia. The charges include sexual assault causing bodily harm and group sexual assault, which carry a maximum penalty of 14 years in prison. The investigation is ongoing, and forensic tests may lead to additional charges. The British High Commission is assisting Canadian authorities with the case.

Four-year-old RJ Jackson suffers from Netherton's syndrome, an extremely rare genetic skin condition that makes his skin appear red, scaly, and inflamed, often resembling burns. His mother, Valerie Jackson, regularly applies creams to manage his symptoms. However, due to the visible nature of his condition, Valerie has faced accusations of child abuse, including a recent incident where armed police were called while she was shopping with RJ. The family also endures public taunts and discrimination, such as being denied entry to play centers. Despite these challenges, Valerie emphasizes RJ's resilience and describes him as a happy, playful child. Netherton's syndrome, a severe form of ichthyosis, has no cure, but symptoms often improve with age. Valerie hopes for greater awareness and understanding of the condition to reduce stigma and ignorance.

Campaigners against Protein World's "Are You Beach Body Ready?" adverts are celebrating as Transport for London (TfL) announced the removal of the controversial posters from the London Underground. The ads, featuring a bikini-clad model, sparked backlash from feminists and body image campaigners, with over 50,000 signatures on a Change.org petition and more than 200 complaints to the Advertising Standards Authority (ASA). Critics argued the ads promoted an unhealthy body image and were sexist. TfL stated the posters were being removed as their three-week advertising period ended, but noted customer feedback would influence future decisions. Protein World defended the campaign, claiming the image was unaltered and aimed at promoting fitness. The controversy escalated with social media outrage, defaced posters, and a planned protest in Hyde Park. The ASA is assessing complaints, while Protein World reported receiving threats, including a bomb threat under police investigation. Despite the backlash, the company plans no changes to its advertising strategy. Sales of protein powder in the UK are rising, reflecting growing fitness trends. Public figures like Katie Hopkins and Samantha Brick supported the campaign, while others, including TV presenter Susanna Reid, criticized it as "anxiety-inducing."

Rail firms have faced criticism for planning significant fare hikes, some as high as 87%, shortly after the general election, despite promises from party leaders to freeze prices. Prime Minister David Cameron has personally intervened, urging First Great Western (FGW) to review its decision to nearly double fares on the London to Cotswolds route, which includes his Witney constituency. FGW claims the changes aim to align the North Cotswolds route with its other services and offers cheaper advance tickets as an alternative. Other rail companies, such as London Midland and Virgin, are also implementing notable fare increases, though Virgin argues its overall fare increase is below the industry average. The planned hikes have sparked public anger, especially as they contradict political pledges to cap or freeze rail fares.

John Young, a 66-year-old former soldier and retired HGV driver, was left blinded in one eye after being struck by a brick thrown by vandals at his home in Oldham, Greater Manchester. The attack occurred on April 18, just three weeks after he married his wife Elaine, 54. The couple was writing thank-you cards for wedding gifts when thugs began throwing stones at their front window. When John opened the door to confront them, a brick was hurled directly at him, causing severe injuries to his left eye. Despite emergency surgery, his eyesight could not be saved. The couple, who had no prior issues in the neighborhood, now feel unsafe and plan to move. Police are investigating the attack but have found no clear motive, suggesting it may have been a senseless act by vandals. Authorities are urging anyone with information to come forward.

Derbyshire wicketkeeper Tom Poynton, 25, has signed a one-year contract extension following his successful return from injury. Poynton missed the entire 2014 season due to leg injuries sustained in a road accident that tragically killed his father, Keith, in April 2014. After undergoing ankle surgery, he made his comeback during Derbyshire's pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi. Poynton will be available for the start of the season and has committed to the county until the end of 2016. Derbyshire's elite performance director, Graeme Welch, praised Poynton's resilience and hard work, expressing hope that the new contract will boost his confidence and performance.

Harley Renshaw, a five-year-old boy from Stretford, was diagnosed with neuroblastoma, a rare and aggressive childhood cancer affecting his kidney, neck, lungs, and bones. During his treatment, which included 80 days of chemotherapy, a stem cell transplant, and radiotherapy, Harley used a Ninja Turtle-themed superhero mask to help him feel brave. His story gained widespread attention, leading to gifts from Nickelodeon and recognition from Cancer Research UK, including a Little Star Award. After a year-long battle, Harley was declared cancer-free. He will undergo regular check-ups to ensure the disease does not return. His family expressed immense joy and hope for his future, as Harley continues to recover and aims to return to school full-time. Neuroblastoma, which affects fewer than 100 children in the UK annually, is a cancer of specialized nerve cells and can spread to various parts of the body.

Tim Sherwood advises Jack Grealish to focus on his Aston Villa career rather than his international future, as the 19-year-old is currently being pursued by both the Republic of Ireland and England. Sherwood emphasizes that Grealish should concentrate on securing a regular spot in Villa's first team before deciding on his international allegiance. Grealish, who impressed in Villa's FA Cup semi-final win over Liverpool, is expected to make his decision at the end of the season. His father, Kevin Grealish, supports Sherwood's advice, stressing that Jack should prioritize his club performance, with international opportunities following naturally. The decision ultimately lies with Grealish, who is currently undecided between the two nations.

The passage discusses the varying landing fees for private jets at different airports worldwide, highlighting some of the most expensive and surprising hubs. Private jet travel is a luxury for the wealthy, with landing fees reaching thousands per trip. The industry is significant, with millions of private flights recorded annually in the US and Europe, and a market worth trillions. Popular routes include Los Angeles to Las Vegas and Milan to Rome. The most expensive airports for landing fees are in Japan, with Haneda Airport in Tokyo being the priciest at £4,559 ($6,850) per landing. Other notable airports in the top 10 include Narita International Airport, Kansai International Airport, and La Guardia Airport in New York. The list also includes unexpected entries like Bristol Airport in the UK and Salzburg Airport in Austria.

Katie Gallegos from Clackamas County, Oregon, took her Labrador, Cooper, and his smaller companion, Daisy, to a McDonald's drive-thru for ice cream. While Daisy licks the ice cream slowly, Cooper devours his portion in one bite, a habit Gallegos notes he always has. The video of this outing has garnered over seven million views, with reactions ranging from finding it cute to criticizing the feeding of ice cream to dogs. Gallegos, who runs a dog resort, defends the practice, stating that Cooper is healthy and that her previous dog also enjoyed weekly ice cream treats. She ensures Daisy gets only small amounts due to her size. The dogs also enjoy "pup-uccinos" from Starbucks, which are simply whipped cream in a cup, with Cooper again consuming his quickly.

Gary Locke has been appointed as the permanent manager of Kilmarnock after signing a three-year contract. He initially joined the club as an assistant to Allan Johnston last summer and took over as interim manager when Johnston left in February. Since taking charge, Locke has lost only one of seven games. He will officially address his new role at a press conference on Friday morning.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp, has accused Seminole County Elementary School of threatening to suspend her five-year-old autistic son, Logan, for wearing essential oils to help manage his condition. Kemp applies Doterra oils, such as lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood, to Logan's neck and head to help him stay calm and focused. The school claims the oils' smell is a distraction to other students and staff, prompting a complaint from a teacher's aide. Despite receiving a letter from the school board stating the oils caused a problem, Kemp insists they benefit her son and vows to fight the decision. The Lake County School District later clarified they would not suspend Logan, calling it a "health issue." Doterra, the company producing the oils, describes their products as "beautifully and powerfully fragrant."

A beachside apartment complex in Westhampton Beach, known as the Sandpiper complex, was destroyed by a massive fire on Wednesday afternoon. The fire, which started at 3 PM, engulfed 90 condos, causing the building to collapse. The blaze was so intense that it melted paint off nearby buildings and produced smoke visible from three miles away. Twelve fire crews attempted to control the flames but were unable to enter the building. The complex, used as a holiday home from May to November, was completely obliterated. Residents, including Janice Sklarek and building manager Rob Taber, expressed shock and devastation, with Taber losing everything. The cause of the fire is under investigation, with initial claims suggesting it may have started near a parked car. Fire Chief Ross Donneson noted that offshore winds aided visibility and firefighting efforts.

The passage describes Queen Elizabeth II's lifelong passion for horses and riding, particularly her preference for riding without a helmet, opting instead for a silk scarf. Despite her age (approaching 89 at the time of the passage) and a knee injury that has reduced her riding time, she continues to enjoy riding her fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, at Windsor Great Park. The Queen has been an equestrian enthusiast since childhood, having received her first pony, Peggy, at age four. She breeds fell ponies and other horse breeds, and her grandchildren also ride some of her horses. The passage also provides historical context about fell ponies, highlighting their origins in Cumbria, their use by various historical groups, and their evolution into a popular riding breed. The Queen's love for horses remains a significant part of her life, even as she has scaled back some of her equestrian activities.

A tragic altercation between two Brisbane neighbors over noise levels resulted in the death of 55-year-old Leon Yeaman. Phillip Pama, a 28-year-old shift worker and father of three, allegedly punched Yeaman during a confrontation after Yeaman was reportedly making loud noise late at night. Yeaman, described as a generous but troubled individual with schizophrenia, died at the scene despite paramedics' efforts. Pama, who has no prior history of violence, was charged with manslaughter and granted conditional bail with strict conditions, including a curfew and regular police check-ins. The case is set to return to court on May 18.

Yulia Simonova, a 52-year-old music teacher, attempted to hire a hitman to torture and murder her 15-year-old former student, Damian Vanya, after he ended their relationship. Simonova offered 100,000 rubles (£1,400) for the hit and provided detailed instructions, including breaking his arms and legs and causing him to bleed out. Unbeknownst to her, the hitman was an undercover police officer, and their meeting was secretly filmed. Simonova was arrested after handing over some money and now faces 15 years in prison for attempted murder. Vanya, who had ended the relationship for a classmate, expressed relief and hoped Simonova would be severely punished.

Jose Mourinho, the Chelsea football manager, revealed in an interview with the Daily Telegraph that he prays daily and speaks to God, but never about football or his professional life. He emphasized his strong faith, stating that he attends church in Portugal when he feels the need. Mourinho, who is 52 and a father of two, strives to separate his professional and family life, describing himself as a good family person and friend. He also mentioned his work as an ambassador against hunger with the World Food Programme, highlighting his awareness of poverty. Despite his competitive and emotional professional demeanor, Mourinho believes he is a good person who supports others. Chelsea, currently leading the league, is set to play QPR this weekend. Earlier in the season, Mourinho was fined for comments about a perceived campaign against Chelsea. He was seen with his family at events like the Hunger Games premiere and the Victoria's Secret fashion show, and his son celebrated Chelsea's Capital One Cup victory with players.

For the first time in eight years, Bob Barker, the legendary host of "The Price is Right" for 35 years, returned to the show on April 1. At 91 years old, Barker hosted the first game, "Lucky Seven," before handing over to the current host, Drew Carey. Despite his long absence, Barker appeared confident and seamless in his role.

An off-duty Secret Service agent, Arthur Baldwin, was arrested in Washington, D.C., early Friday morning for allegedly attempting to break into a house and causing property damage. Arrested at 12:30 a.m. on the 3200 block of D Street SE, Baldwin faces felony charges of attempted burglary and destruction of property. Following his arrest, Baldwin, who is assigned to the Foreign Missions Branch of the Secret Service, had his security clearance revoked and was placed on leave. His arrest occurred two days after another high-ranking supervisor was placed on leave due to misconduct allegations, both incidents adding to recent controversies within the agency. Baldwin was scheduled for arraignment Friday afternoon, and the Homeland Security Department's Inspector General is investigating the misconduct allegations. These events follow a March 4 incident involving two high-ranking officials accused of driving into a secure White House area after drinking.

A freelance photographer, Atif Saeed, 38, from Lahore, Pakistan, risked his life to capture close-up images of a hungry lion at the city's safari park. Armed only with a camera, Saeed crept within 10 feet of the lion, lying on the ground to take photos. However, the sound of the camera shutter alerted the lion, which aggressively jumped towards him. Saeed narrowly escaped by scrambling back into his car. Reflecting on the incident, he admitted it was a close encounter and doubted he would attempt such a feat again.

The New York City Police have released an image of a distinctive tattoo found on the body of an unidentified woman who died on a Brooklyn street nearly a month ago. The woman, believed to be between 25 and 45 years old, was found unconscious on March 22 near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn. Paramedics were unable to revive her, and she was pronounced dead that evening. The tattoo, located on her right leg, features the name "Monique" etched across a ribbon within a heart topped with a rose. Police are awaiting a medical examiner's report to determine the cause of death and are asking anyone with information to contact NYPD Crime Stoppers.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, built a solar-powered, two-bedroom home on the back of a 1986 Hino flatbed truck after returning from the UK in 2009. Unable to afford traditional property, they spent a year and a half constructing the home, which features a wood and steel frame, wood-fired stove, stained glass windows, and other comforts. Located in Nelson, New Zealand, the home is nearly self-sufficient, with solar panels providing most of the electricity, gas-powered stove and hot water, and water sourced from a nearby spring. The project cost approximately $25,000, and the couple now enjoys a cozy, nature-surrounded lifestyle with their cat. They even plan to build another similar home in the future.

Researchers found that children who share iPads in class perform significantly better in early literacy tests compared to those who use iPads individually or do not use them at all. The study, conducted by Courtney Blackwell at Northwestern University, involved 352 kindergarten students and revealed that shared iPad users scored around 30 points higher than their peers. The findings suggest that collaborative learning around the technology, rather than the technology itself, drives the improvement. Blackwell recommends reconsidering how tablets are used in early grades to maximize their effectiveness. The results will be presented at the International Communication Association's annual conference.

A two-legged piglet, born without hind legs, has become an internet sensation after a video showed it learning to walk and balance on its front trotters. The piglet, nicknamed "Super Pig," belongs to farmer Ms. Duan from Qionglai City in Sichuan Province, China. Despite its disability, the piglet manages to forage for food and interact with its fully-legged siblings. The heartwarming video has captured the attention of thousands, with villagers and online viewers alike marveling at its resilience and balance. This is not the first time a two-legged animal has gained fame in China, as a similar case involved a rabbit at Liuzhou Zoo.

During the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana on Sunday, Todd Phillips, a front-outside tire changer for Dale Coyne Racing, was injured when he was struck by Francesco Dracone's car. Dracone, who had pitted on lap 25 for tires and fuel, spun while exiting his pit box, clipping Phillips' leg. Phillips was treated at the infield care center, receiving stitches for a leg cut, and was later released. The race was challenging due to rain affecting traction, and Dracone did not finish, ending up in 23rd place.

A 32-year-old man, Milton Vieira Severiano, brutally murdered his 29-year-old wife, Cicera Alves de Sena, a dancer with the group Jaula das Gostozuedas, in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. The attack, captured on CCTV, involved Severiano smashing his wife's head into concrete 11 times, punching her face 10 times, and then shooting her in the face five times at close range. Severiano confessed to the crime, citing jealousy over men looking at his wife as his motive. The couple had been married for only four days. After the murder, Severiano stole a neighbor's car but was arrested following a crash. Police found multiple firearms and a bulletproof vest in his car. He now faces life imprisonment.

Sarah Wilson, a journalist and author of the best-selling book *I Quit Sugar*, has shared her personal struggle with mental illness, revealing that she nearly took her own life due to severe anxiety. In a candid interview, Wilson explained how her anxiety, combined with stress, thyroid disease, and feelings of isolation from her distant family, led her to believe her life was no longer worth living. She described feeling alone and unable to see a way out, but has since found some peace. Wilson emphasizes the link between depression and anxiety, urging greater awareness to address the rising rates of stress and anxiety among Australian women. She notes that anxiety is becoming the "new depression," with one in three Australian women likely to experience it in their lifetime. Wilson encourages seeking help through resources like Beyond Blue and Lifeline.

Elena Curtin, a seven-months pregnant woman from Portland, Oregon, was charged with second-degree assault in November 2014 after she beat her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend with a crowbar. The incident occurred when Curtin found the ex-girlfriend using heroin in her bathroom and asked her to leave, but the woman refused. Oregon law permits the use of physical force against an intruder who refuses to leave a resident's home. Prosecutors dropped the charges against Curtin, stating her actions were "completely justified in her outrage." Curtin's defense attorney highlighted a history of harassment and threats from the ex-girlfriend, who had a child with Curtin's boyfriend and had previously struggled with heroin addiction. Curtin, who has since given birth and reconciled with her boyfriend, is now living with her parents. The boyfriend has not been involved in their new child's life. If convicted, Curtin faced a mandatory six-year prison sentence.

Gemma, a pit bull in California, was filmed being fed treats by her owner, who included a broccoli spear to trick her. Gemma reacted with disgust, chewing the broccoli before spitting it out. The video highlights her dislike for the vegetable, with a humorous note hoping the children she lives with don't follow her example and instead learn to enjoy their greens. When not eating, Gemma enjoys sleeping and spending time with her human family.

HSBC apologized after a link on its official website mistakenly directed visitors to a pornographic page. The link, which was intended for the Young Entrepreneur Awards page (discontinued in 2011), redirected users to a porn site after the original page's registration expired. HSBC removed the hyperlink upon discovering the error and issued a public statement clarifying that it had no association with the external site. The bank assured the public that its website remained secure and apologized for any inconvenience caused. HSBC's internet banking services, including account management and financial transactions, were unaffected.

A 13-year-old Maryland boy, Marcus, called 911 during a house fire in Clinton, providing clear instructions to firefighters while staying calm throughout the 11-minute call. Trapped in a second-floor bedroom with his 9-year-old sister Aaliyah, Marcus reassured her and guided rescuers to their location. Firefighters entered the home, broke a window, and rescued both children. Marcus and Aaliyah were taken to Children's Hospital with non-life-threatening injuries, while three other family members escaped on their own and were taken to MedStar Hospital. Firefighters praised Marcus's composure and actions as heroic.

Stunning images of blue fluorescent algae illuminating Australia's east coast, particularly Jervis Bay in New South Wales, have emerged. Photographer Andy Hutchinson described the phenomenon as a "beautiful supernatural scene" caused by millions of plankton emitting light. A similar event occurred at Sydney's Manly Beach in August 2014. According to oceanography expert Iain Suthers from the University of New South Wales, the glow is caused by *Noctiluca scintillans*, a single-celled phytoplankton that blooms in spring and autumn, primarily due to natural causes. This carnivorous algae emits light as a defense mechanism and preys on another type of algae called diatoms.

New genetic tests, such as EndoPredict, are enabling breast cancer patients to avoid unnecessary chemotherapy by identifying genetic markers in tumors to assess their aggressiveness. These tests can determine the risk of cancer recurrence, with some women having as low as a 5% risk, making chemotherapy potentially unnecessary. Traditionally, most breast cancer patients undergo chemotherapy post-surgery to prevent recurrence, despite its severe side effects. The tests, currently available privately for around £2,500, could soon be accessible through the NHS, potentially saving costs by reducing chemotherapy use. Experts believe these tests allow patients to make informed decisions about their treatment, as demonstrated by a patient who avoided chemotherapy after a low-risk score. Regular monitoring is emphasized as a key strategy for early detection of any recurrence.

The passage reveals that over 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy, with HMS Ocean having five such cases in nine years. At least one woman was evacuated from HMS Illustrious. A strict "no touching" rule at sea suggests pregnancies occurred before boarding or during leave. The data follows an incident involving Commander Sarah West, the first woman to captain a Royal Navy warship, who was investigated for alleged misconduct. Women have served on Royal Navy ships since 1990, with 9% of personnel being female in 2014. Additionally, nearly 100 female soldiers were sent home from Afghanistan between 2006 and 2013 due to pregnancy, with similar evacuations from Iraq. Strict military rules prohibit pregnant women from serving in war zones, and most pregnancies likely occurred before deployment.

A drone carrying traces of radioactive cesium, a byproduct of nuclear reactors, was discovered on the rooftop of Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's residence in Tokyo. The drone, equipped with a camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle containing the radioactive material, was found on the same day a court approved the restart of two reactors at the Sendai nuclear power plant. While the amount of cesium was not immediately harmful, the incident has raised concerns about potential terrorism involving drones, particularly ahead of major events like the Olympics and G7 summit. Japanese officials emphasized the need to review drone regulations and enhance security measures to prevent such threats. Abe was not present at the time, as he was attending a conference in Indonesia.

Lu Xincai, a security guard from Zhejiang Province, China, takes his 84-year-old mother, who suffers from Alzheimer's, to work with him every day on his motorbike. Concerned she might get lost if left alone, he ties a sash around both of them for safety and rides slowly to ensure her comfort. His mother has her own room at his workplace, a bank, where he checks on her regularly. Lu's dedication stems from his belief in repaying her lifelong care for him, as she once carried him on her back during her work. His story has resonated widely, highlighting his deep familial devotion.

A major study by the University of Washington's Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation reveals that heavy drinking and binge drinking among Americans increased significantly between 2005 and 2012, with a 17.2% rise in heavy drinking. This increase is largely driven by women, whose binge drinking rates grew more than seven times faster than men's over the decade. Heavy drinking is defined as exceeding one drink per day for women and two for men, while binge drinking involves four or more drinks for women and five or more for men on a single occasion. The study, published in the *American Journal of Public Health*, attributes the rise to changing social norms, economic factors, and weakened alcohol control policies. In 2012, 8% of Americans were heavy drinkers, and 18% were binge drinkers. Alcohol-related deaths and costs remain high, with 88,600 deaths attributed to alcohol in 2010 and excessive drinking costing over $220 billion annually. The study also highlights regional variations, with some counties reporting significantly higher rates of binge and heavy drinking than others.

UN officials warn that doctors are performing caesarean sections too readily, putting the health of women and babies at risk. They emphasize that the procedure should only be done when medically necessary, as it can lead to infections, complications, disability, or even death. In England, over 25% of births are now by caesarean, more than double the rate since the 1990s, with many women opting for planned caesareans due to anxiety about natural birth. The World Health Organization (WHO) states that the ideal rate should be between 10% and 15%, citing the dangers and costs involved. A planned caesarean costs the NHS significantly more than a natural birth. WHO's stance contradicts current NHS guidelines, which allow caesareans even without medical justification, including for women with tokophobia (fear of childbirth) or other conditions. WHO argues that doctors are underestimating the risks, with research showing that up to 10% of caesareans result in infections.

A 44-year-old woman, Michelle Filkins from West Wareham, was arrested on April 17 after allegedly breaking into a summer home on Martha's Vineyard, living there for at least a week, and selling the owners' belongings in a yard sale. The homeowner, Mark Conklin, discovered Filkins in his $800,000 property on Court Street in Edgartown. When confronted, Filkins claimed ownership of the house before fleeing in a gray Nissan pickup truck. Police found a broken window covered by a blanket and arrested Filkins hours later when she attempted to re-enter the home. She faces charges of breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. Missing items include furniture, lamps, a painting, and household goods. Police urge anyone who received items from the home to return them and contact the Edgartown Police Department. Filkins is scheduled to appear in court on May 14.

A lost iPhone belonging to Bella Crooke from Melbourne was handed in to Albury Police Station on the NSW-Victoria border. Police discovered the phone was unlocked and used it to post humorous selfies and photos on Bella's Facebook page to locate her. The posts included puns and updates about the phone being in a "holding cell" and fully "charged." Bella, who lost her phone at a friend's birthday party, eventually reclaimed it without needing to provide her name, as officers recognized her from Facebook. The police's creative approach garnered praise from Bella and her friends, and she has since secured her phone with a password.

A five-day-old baby hippopotamus was tragically killed after being caught in a fight between two adult male hippos in the iSimangaliso Wetland Park, South Africa. The calf was thrown into the air and dragged through the water by one of the males during the altercation. The mother, who had been protecting her calf from other hippos, watched helplessly as the incident unfolded. Despite her attempts to intervene, the calf sustained fatal injuries and died hours later. The fight between the two males had been ongoing, and the mother's decision to stay with her herd likely contributed to the calf's vulnerability. A tour operator witnessed the event, describing the mother's efforts to protect her calf and the tragic outcome.

A three-bedroom apartment in Knightsbridge, London, one of Britain's most expensive areas, is on the market for £575,000, significantly cheaper than neighboring properties. However, the "bargain" comes with a major catch: the lease has only three years remaining. Extending the lease could cost between £3.35 and £4.5 million for a 90-year term, potentially increasing the property's value to over £6 million. The 1,990 sq/ft flat is described as "bright and well-proportioned" but requires significant renovation. A second, larger maisonette in the same area is also available for £595,000 with a similarly short lease. Estate agents note that such short-lease properties are rare in Knightsbridge, and the listings have generated significant interest. However, potential buyers are warned about the high costs of lease extensions and the risks of letting leases run down.

Starbucks experienced a computer outage on Friday evening that affected sales registers at 8,000 stores in the U.S. and Canada, leading to free drink giveaways by baristas. The outage, caused by a failure during a daily system refresh, prevented credit card transactions but allowed cash payments. Many stores closed early to avoid further free product distribution. Despite the disruption, Starbucks announced the issue was resolved, and stores would reopen for normal business on Saturday. The incident occurred just after the company reported record quarterly earnings of $4.6 billion. Social media buzzed with customer reactions, ranging from excitement over free drinks to disappointment as some locations closed prematurely.

The passage reveals that rural areas in West Wales, specifically Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire, are being used for terrorist training and radicalisation activities, according to an officer from the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit. These activities are often disguised as ordinary community events but have underlying extremist motives. Historical incidents include the 1998 training of extremists in the Brecon Beacons, the 2005 presence of 7/7 bombers at a whitewater centre, and the 2010 arrest of a Cardiff-based terror group. Additionally, Michael Adebowale, convicted of murdering Fusilier Lee Rigby, studied at a local institute linked to Iraqi clerics. Authorities stress the importance of community intelligence in combating these activities.

A juvenile female Omura's whale, a species previously feared extinct, was found washed up on a remote beach in Exmouth, Western Australia, following Tropical Cyclone Olwyn. This marks the first sighting of the species in Western Australia and only the second in Australia. Initially difficult to identify, the 5.68-meter whale was confirmed through DNA profiling. The discovery is significant for scientists, as little is known about the species, which was first described in scientific journals in 2003 and is typically found in tropical and subtropical waters like those of Indonesia, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan. The whale's carcass has been buried, with plans to recover the skeleton in a few years for further scientific study and potential public display in museums. Omura's whales are noted for their sleek body shape and unique skeletal features, including 53 vertebrae and four digits on each pectoral fin.

The passage discusses the role of hormones in presidential leadership, sparked by comments from Cheryl Rios, a businesswoman who argues that women, due to their hormones, should not be president. Rios's views have been criticized, with counterarguments highlighting that male leaders have also made poor decisions influenced by hormones. Studies suggest women leaders take fewer unnecessary risks than men. The broader issue of gender bias in leadership is emphasized, with evidence showing persistent workplace biases against women. The passage argues that gender equality benefits society economically and socially, and calls for a serious discussion on ending gender bias to enable true equality. Hillary Clinton's potential presidency is used as a case study to illustrate the challenges women face in leadership roles. The passage concludes by advocating for a societal shift in perceptions and support for women's leadership capabilities.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy, aged 89, is auctioning over 200 antiques from his extensive collection, valued at £100,000, as he downsizes his home. Known for roles in *All Creatures Great and Small* and as Winston Churchill, Hardy is also a military historian and longbow expert. The auction, managed by Dominic Winter Auctioneers in Gloucestershire, includes unique items like a hand-painted diorama of the Battle of Agincourt, a yew longbow, and a portrait of Hardy holding the bow. Other items include Victorian furniture, swords, rifles, silverware, and 17th-century books. Hardy, a former student of J.R.R. Tolkien and C.S. Lewis, expressed sadness at parting with his collection but hopes the new owners will cherish the items as he did. Despite retiring from stage acting after a fall, he plans to continue television work.

Michael Scott Shemansky is a suspect in the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, 57, who was found dead in their Winter Garden, Florida home. Shemansky failed to appear for a supervised visit with his son on the same day his mother was discovered dead, prompting police to name him as a suspect. He has a history of bipolar disorder, was previously on parole for battery on law enforcement, and had been involuntarily committed for a suicide attempt. Neighbors suggest that ongoing divorce proceedings and recent bad news may have contributed to his actions. Shemansky was last seen fleeing on foot without provisions or medication. Authorities have the murder weapon but have not disclosed details of the killing. His estranged wife is taking precautions in case he contacts her. Police urge anyone with information to contact them.

The city of Eugene in the United States has been awarded the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships. This decision was made by the International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF) Council, which bypassed the usual bidding process due to a unique strategic opportunity to host the event in the USA for the first time. Eugene had previously failed to secure the 2019 event, which was awarded to Doha, Qatar. However, a recent presentation convinced the IAAF that Eugene is capable of hosting the championships. IAAF President Lamine Diack emphasized the strategic importance of this decision, highlighting the collaboration between public authorities, the private sector, the national Olympic committee, NBC, and an enthusiastic public. The decision aligns with the IAAF's goal of expanding the sport's global reach, similar to the 2007 World Championships in Osaka, Japan, which were also awarded without a bidding process.

Leonie Granger, a 25-year-old aspiring model, was sentenced to 16 years in prison for the manslaughter of professional gambler Mehmet Hassan, 56. Granger lured Hassan at a London casino, befriending him to gain access to his wealth. She left his flat door unlocked one night, allowing her boyfriend Kyrron Jackson and accomplice Nicholas Chandler to enter. They tied Hassan up, kicked him to death, and ransacked his home for his hidden cash. Jackson and Chandler were convicted of murder and sentenced to life with a minimum of 36 years. The judge described the attack as "pitiless and wicked." Granger, who claimed she was influenced by her love for Jackson, was found guilty by a majority verdict. The trio also faced convictions for robbery and conspiracy to falsely imprison Hassan. Hassan's family expressed deep grief over his brutal death.

Cesc Fàbregas, Chelsea's midfielder, has experienced a significant dip in form during the second half of the season, a trend noted by his former club Barcelona. Despite a strong start to the season, where he was on track to break the Premier League assist record, his performance has declined, with only one assist in his last five games. This slump was evident in Spain's 2-0 defeat to the Netherlands, where Fàbregas struggled to make an impact. Chelsea manager José Mourinho is concerned about Fàbregas's fatigue and form as the team approaches the final games of the season. However, with nine games left, there is still potential for Fàbregas to contribute significantly to Chelsea's title charge, especially against teams he has previously performed well against. Mourinho hopes for a late-season resurgence from Fàbregas to secure the Premier League title.

West Ham is close to signing 17-year-old Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford, who impressed during a two-week trial with the club's academy. Beckford, considered one of the Caribbean's top prospects, also has offers from Belgian clubs. Additionally, West Ham announced that season tickets for the Olympic Stadium will start at £289, making them the cheapest in the Premier League, as the club aims to fill the 54,000-seat stadium for the 2016-17 season.

The passage describes a violent assault on Mike Lane, a 40-year-old huntsman, by balaclava-clad protesters during a hunt in Everleigh, near Amesbury. Despite providing Wiltshire Police with a video of the incident, a dossier of evidence, and car registration numbers of suspects, the investigation was dropped due to insufficient evidence. Lane, who suffered concussion, broken teeth, and memory loss, criticized the police decision as "pathetic." The attack occurred while the hunt was using an artificial scent, not a live fox. Protesters sprayed hounds with citronella and engaged in violent behavior, including kicking Lane in the head. The police issued a photograph of the main suspect but failed to identify or charge anyone. The decision to halt the investigation has drawn criticism from Lane, hunt supporters, and the Countryside Alliance, which is advocating for a ban on face coverings to help identify criminals. Wiltshire Police stated the case remains open if new evidence emerges.

Adam Gadahn, a prominent American member of Al Qaeda known as "Azzam the American," was killed in January during a U.S. counterterrorism operation. Born in 1978, Gadahn converted to Islam in 1995 and moved to Pakistan in 1998, where he joined Al Qaeda. He became a key English-language propagandist for the group, appearing in videos threatening attacks and urging Muslims to target Western interests. Indicted for treason and material support to Al Qaeda in 2006, he was on the FBI's "most wanted terrorists" list. Gadahn also criticized U.S. presidents and encouraged lone-wolf attacks in the U.S. He was married to an Afghan woman and had at least one child. His death was announced by the White House, which also confirmed the deaths of two other U.S. citizens, including a hostage, in separate operations.

A five-year-old Chinese boy named Mai Zizhuo has gained widespread attention in China for his exceptional basketball skills, showcased in a viral video. Mai, who has been playing basketball since he was two and a half, demonstrates impressive abilities, including dribbling two basketballs simultaneously and scoring multiple hoops. His talent has earned him a large fan base in basketball-loving China, with many netizens expressing amazement and even self-deprecating humor about their own skills in comparison. Mai's rise comes in a country where parents are passionate about nurturing child prodigies, and he is being compared to China's most famous basketball star, Yao Ming.

Tom O'Carroll, a prominent member of the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE), which campaigned to legalize child sex in the 1970s and 1980s, has joined the media pressure group Hacked Off. O'Carroll, a former activist for PIE, attended a Hacked Off rally in the Houses of Parliament on February 25 to lobby MPs for state involvement in media regulation. Hacked Off, established after the phone-hacking scandal, advocates for a statutory body to regulate the press, as recommended by the Leveson Inquiry. O'Carroll's support for Hacked Off is seen as an embarrassment to the group. PIE, formed in 1974, sought to legalize sex with children and incest, and O'Carroll was involved with the National Council for Civil Liberties' gay rights sub-committee. He was jailed in 1981 for "corrupting public morals" and confirmed his attendance at the Hacked Off meeting in a blog post. The meeting was chaired by comedian John Cleese and was open to the public.

The Bondi Icebergs Club pool was drained on Thursday to serve as a unique catwalk for the Ten Pieces presentation during Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. The event featured a monochrome, unisex capsule collection designed to be worn in 20 different ways, suitable for day-to-night wear. Models walked through the empty pool and along the break wall with the ocean as a backdrop. The show, attended by guests who enjoyed food and drinks, took place on a warm 28°C day, attracting attention from beachgoers and passers-by. Ten Pieces, led by Icebergs restaurateur Maurice Terzini and Lucy Hinckfuss, showcased minimalist, androgynous designs, including scarves and hoodies, blending fashion with the iconic Bondi setting.

Amir Khan, a Bolton-born boxer, spent a family day at Six Flags Discovery Kingdom in Northern California, where he and his wife, Faryal Makhdoom Khan, and daughter, Lamysa, interacted with animals, including a rare white tiger, giraffes, and sea lions. During this time, Khan also announced his next fight against former light-welterweight world champion Chris Algieri on May 30, ending speculation about his next opponent. This decision came despite pressure to face British rival and IBF welterweight champion Kell Brook in June, as well as links to potential bouts against Adrien Broner and Keith Thurman.

A Palestinian teenager, Mohammed Abu Khdeir, who was beaten and burned alive by three Israelis in July, had his name mistakenly included on an Israeli memorial wall at Jerusalem's Mount Herzl, which honors fallen soldiers and victims of terrorism. His family and the organization Almagor, which represents Israeli terror victims, objected to his inclusion, arguing that his death was a rogue attack and not an act of terrorism. Following complaints, the National Insurance Institute of Israel agreed to remove Abu Khdeir's name from the memorial. Meanwhile, a trial against the suspects in his killing is ongoing.

A young boy in California, filmed by his father Lionel Hutz, uses his cat's belly as a pillow to rest his head. The video shows the boy chasing the cat around the garden, lying on it briefly before the cat moves away. This sequence repeats until the cat eventually retreats indoors. Later, the boy and the cat reconcile, with the boy feeding the cat treats. The footage captures the playful yet persistent interaction between the child and the feline.

A police corruption trial in Philadelphia involves over a dozen former drug dealers, including Robert Kushner, testifying against six former police officers accused of racketeering, extortion, robbery, kidnapping, and drug dealing. Kushner, who lost his coaching job at a private academy after testifying about his past marijuana sales, revealed that officers stole $81,000 and 7 pounds of marijuana from him during a 2007 arrest. Despite passing a background check in 2010, his criminal history, including a 2011 arrest and a 2008 DUI, came to light during the trial. Kushner expressed remorse and claimed innocence regarding the 2011 charges, emphasizing his commitment to moving past his earlier mistakes. The defense argues that the case relies on unreliable witnesses, including Kushner and other former drug dealers.

An explosion at a paraxylene (PX) chemical plant in Zhangzhou City, Fujian Province, China, caused a large fire and injured six people, with five hospitalized due to broken glass. The blast occurred at an oil storage facility after an oil leak, but no toxic chemical spill was reported. Over 600 firefighters were deployed, and the fire is now under control. The plant, which produces a reportedly carcinogenic chemical used in polyester production, has faced public opposition due to pollution concerns, leading to protests and its relocation from Xiamen to Zhangzhou in 2007. This is not the first incident at the plant, as it experienced another explosion in 2013 without casualties or toxic leaks.

Jack Grealish, an Aston Villa teenager and Ireland under-21 international, is known for wearing his socks low above his children-sized shinpads, a habit he maintains due to superstition. Despite referees urging him to pull his socks up, Grealish insists on keeping them low, as he has done all his life. He recently made his first Premier League start in a 3-3 draw against QPR, a game he found challenging but was pleased to have started, expressing gratitude for his manager's confidence in him. Grealish hopes to secure more starts before the season ends.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, the 22-year-old daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has "global and irreversible brain damage," according to her grandmother, Cissy Houston. Although she is no longer in a medically induced coma, she remains unresponsive and does not react to visitors or familiar voices. Doctors have indicated that she could live in this condition indefinitely, and she has a tracheostomy in her throat. Despite her father, Bobby Brown, claiming her condition had improved and that she was "awake," her grandmother and a source familiar with her condition stated she remains in the same neurological state she has been in for nearly three months. The family's attorney noted that while doctors believe she will have a long life, the quality of her life remains uncertain as she begins a lengthy rehabilitation process.

Russia is close to reaching the Fed Cup final after taking a 2-0 lead against Germany. Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova saved a match point and defeated Sabine Lisicki 4-6, 7-6 (4), 6-3, following Svetlana Kuznetsova's straight-sets victory over Julia Goerges. Pavlyuchenkova struggled with Lisicki's powerful play but managed to secure the win despite 13 double faults, while Lisicki's 63 unforced errors were costly. Russia needs just one more win from Sunday's matches to advance to the final and potentially claim their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

Residents of New South Wales (NSW), already impacted by last week's severe weather, are warned to prepare for more floods and damage as another storm is predicted to hit later this week. Meteorologists indicate that an east coast low, similar to the system that caused three days of heavy rain and wind last week, could bring heavy rain from Thursday through Saturday. The State Emergency Service (SES) is concerned about the impact on clean-up efforts, with over 4,000 jobs still pending from last week's 24,196 requests. The Hunter region, particularly hard-hit by the previous storm, is a major focus for SES, as further rain could worsen flooding and wind could topple already uprooted trees. Weather forecasts predict heavy rain and strong winds, especially in the state's northeast, with rainfall expected to peak between Thursday and Saturday. The SES is urging residents to prepare their homes and families to mitigate further damage. Over 1,000 personnel, including 200 from other states, are assisting in the field. The severity of the upcoming weather system remains uncertain, but it is expected to be less intense than last week's storm.

Nina Moric, a 38-year-old model who appeared in Ricky Martin's "La Vida Loca" music video, denied reports that she attempted suicide over the weekend. Italian media had claimed she was found by her mother in her Milan apartment after a suicide attempt, and her boyfriend allegedly supported this narrative. However, Moric clarified on Instagram that she was hospitalized due to low blood pressure and a domestic accident, where she fell and injured herself. She posted photos of her bruises and reassured fans she was recovering at home, emphasizing she had no intention of ending her life. Moric also expressed shock at the suicide claims and stated her boyfriend was in Naples at the time of the incident. Additionally, Italian media referenced a past incident in 2009 where Moric allegedly attempted suicide, but she did not address this in her recent posts. Moric was previously married to Fabrizio Corona, a notorious paparazzo jailed for blackmailing celebrities, with whom she shares a son.

As Kate and William prepare for the arrival of their second child, a YouGov poll for *The Sunday Times* reveals that the British public favors the name Diana if the baby is a girl, with 12% of respondents supporting this choice as a tribute to William's late mother, Princess Diana. Other popular names for a girl include Alice and Charlotte, each receiving 9% of the vote. If the child is a boy, James and Alexander are the top choices, with 13% and a lower percentage, respectively, favoring these names. A quarter of the 2,200 people polled hope for a baby girl, while only 3% wish for a younger brother for Prince George. Additionally, 68% of Brits support William's decision to take six weeks of paternity leave. Social media users have also expressed enthusiasm for the name Diana, with many hoping it will be used as either a first or middle name.

A suicide bomber attacked a group of protesters in Khost, eastern Afghanistan, killing 17 people and injuring 64, including an Afghan lawmaker. The protesters were heading to a rally against the provincial governor. The Taliban denied responsibility, and no other group has claimed the attack. The incident occurred around 10 a.m. local time.

Dani Alves is set to leave Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club's final contract offer. The 31-year-old Brazilian right-back, who has spent seven successful years at Barcelona, winning four Spanish titles and the Champions League twice, was unable to agree on a new deal. His agent, Dinorah Santana, confirmed that Alves turned down a three-year contract extension, which was contingent on him playing in 60% of the club's matches. Santana expressed frustration over the timing of the negotiations, stating that it was unreasonable for Barcelona to wait until April to address his contract renewal.

Pablo Osvaldo, currently on loan at Boca Juniors from Southampton, has urged Italian football legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at the Argentinian club. Osvaldo, who has scored three goals in six games, believes the duo would be a perfect fit for Boca due to their South American-style play and exceptional abilities. He expressed that the fans at La Bombonera would be thrilled to see them play. Pirlo is renowned as one of the world's best midfielders, while Totti is a Roma legend, and Osvaldo is confident they would be equally adored in Argentina.

Lewis Ferguson, an 18-year-old amateur jockey, experienced a dramatic double somersault fall from his horse, Merrion Square, during a race at Wincanton. Despite the incident, which went viral online, Ferguson only suffered a cut on his nose and returned to riding the next day. He described the fall as a blur and expressed gratitude for his luck, noting the support from fellow jockeys. Ferguson also humorously suggested considering a gymnastics career after racing, while embracing the banter and newfound attention on social media.

James Haskell, the England flanker and London Wasps captain, celebrated the release of the movie *Avengers: Age of Ultron* by posting a photo on Instagram dressed as Iron Man, Robert Downey Jr.'s character. The movie premiered in London with a star-studded cast. Haskell, who returned to Wasps in 2012 after playing in France, Japan, and New Zealand, has since surpassed 100 appearances for the club and earned 57 caps for England. His career includes stints with Stade Français, Ricoh Black Rams, and Highlanders before rejoining Wasps, where he began his professional rugby journey in 2002.

The passage discusses the resurgence of the wide-leg trouser as a key trend for SS15, offering an alternative to the long-dominant skinny jean. Wide-leg trousers, available in various styles like denim, cropped, printed, or striped, are praised for their effortless appeal. The trend, which has made comebacks since the 1970s, can be intimidating for shorter individuals, but pairing them with high heels and simple tops can create a flattering look. Denim is highlighted as the easiest way to adopt the trend, with brands like Gucci and Topshop offering vintage-inspired options. Celine and Stella McCartney presented dressier versions suitable for evening wear. The trend is versatile, not weather-dependent, and can update one's wardrobe for the season. For more inspiration, the passage directs readers to astylealbum.com.
